title: Testing 2025 Prophecies: Jeremiah Johnson & Cindy Jacobs
description:
Jeremiah Johnson and Cindy Jacob both delivered national-stage prophetic words for the year 2025. Did they get it right or miss? We're putting their prophetic declarations to the test as we're commanded to do in 1 Thessalonians 5:20‚Äì21.

As we examine their messages, we'll walk you through the practical theology of prophetic accountability, exploring what Scripture says about holding prophets to their words, and discussing why this matters so much for the health of the charismatic church.

Whether you're charismatic, cessationist, or somewhere in between, this conversation on Christian discernment is crucial for anyone navigating prophetic ministry, spiritual gifts, and biblical prophecy in the modern church. We're chasing that radical middle between Word and Spirit‚Äîholding fast to Scripture while honoring the prophetic gift.

Join the conversation, test everything, and hold fast to what is good.

title: Spellbound: The Story of Charisma in America (with Molly Worthen)
description:
What happens when the power of the Holy Spirit collides with the chaos of American politics? Join Joshua Lewis as he sits down with historian Molly Worthen to explore her book Spellbound, which traces the fascinating and often controversial story of charisma‚Äîboth spiritual and political‚Äîfrom Puritan prophets to modern-day leaders like Donald Trump.

We explore the tension between institutional authority and personal revelation that has defined American Christianity and culture for centuries. Discover how figures like Anne Hutchinson challenged Puritan ministers by claiming direct assurance from the Holy Spirit, how George Whitefield revolutionized preaching with theatrical emotion, and how Joseph Smith blended enlightenment rationalism with spiritual experience to birth Mormonism.

Professor Worthen, a historian at UNC Chapel Hill, reveals how charismatic leaders aren't always the charming orators we imagine‚Äîinstead, they're polarizing storytellers who invite followers into transcendent narratives that give suffering and struggle cosmic significance. We explore the dangerous line between prophetic truth and spiritual manipulation, examining everyone from radical Quaker Benjamin Lay to Martin Luther King Jr., and asking the crucial question: how do we test the spirits in an age of radical individualism?

Whether you're fascinated by church history, concerned about discernment in charismatic movements, or trying to understand the spiritual undercurrents shaping our political moment, this episode offers essential insights into how divine power‚Äîor the claim to it‚Äîhas shaped the American experiment.

0:00 ‚Äì Introduction
0:46 ‚Äì Molly's background and ministry
4:49 ‚Äì Defining charisma
20:11 ‚Äì Anne Hutchinson & Puritan Massachusetts
30:00 ‚Äì Donna Beatrice & the Congo rebellion
36:25 ‚Äì George Fox & the Quaker movement
44:01 ‚Äì George Whitefield & emotional preaching
50:28 ‚Äì Charisma & American individualism
54:05 ‚Äì Joseph Smith & the Mormon church
1:00:14 ‚Äì Closing thoughts on charisma & discernment

title: Testing 2025 Prophecies: Emma Stark, Kay Nash & Tomi Arayomi
description:
Did the prophets get it right? We're putting prophetic words to the test! Join us as we review the major prophecies spoken over 2025 by Emma Stark, Kay Nash, and Tomi Arayomi‚Äîexamining what hit, what missed, and what we can learn from the process. As Scripture commands us to test all things and weigh prophetic words carefully, we're diving deep into biblical discernment and accountability in the prophetic movement.

In this end-of-year episode, the Remnant Radio crew breaks down prophetic declarations given at the start of 2025, comparing them against real-world events and spiritual markers we've witnessed throughout the year. We'll discuss the hits, the misses, and the "jury's still out" moments with honesty and biblical integrity. Our goal is to uphold the standard Scripture gives us for testing prophecy and holding modern prophets accountable to God's Word.

We'll explore critical questions every believer should ask: How do we properly test prophetic words according to 1 Thessalonians 5:20-21? What separates genuine prophetic insight from wishful thinking or cultural commentary? How should the body of Christ respond when prophecies don't come to pass? And what does biblical discernment look like in an age of viral prophetic declarations?

Whether you're navigating the prophetic movement, curious about spiritual gifts, or simply want to grow in biblical discernment, this episode offers practical wisdom rooted in Scripture. We're committed to honoring authentic moves of the Holy Spirit while maintaining the accountability that protects God's people from deception. As we close out 2025, join us for an honest conversation about prophecy, discernment, and what it means to test everything and hold fast to what is good.

3:26 ‚Äì Theology of prophecy and why we review national words
8:20 ‚Äì Tomi Arayomi‚Äôs prophecy
28:34 ‚Äì Kay Nash prophecy
45:59 ‚Äì Emma Stark / Sam Robertson prophecy

title: Transform Your Faith: Why Lent Matters for Every Believer with Elyse Fitzpatrick
description:
Ever feel like your church calendar skips straight from Christmas cheer to Easter celebration‚Äîmissing something crucial in between? You're not alone, and Lent might be the answer.

Join Joshua Lewis and author Elyse Fitzpatrick to understand why Lent matters for every believer‚Äînot just the high church crowd. Elyse shares her transformative Ash Wednesday experience during the pandemic and why spending 40 days reflecting on Christ's suffering changed everything about her faith.

This isn't about earning brownie points with God through religious rituals. It's about understanding that before glory comes suffering‚Äîand why Western Christianity desperately needs to recover this truth. Elyse unpacks how fasting reveals our weakness so we can rest in Christ's strength, and why biblical lament looks nothing like hopeless despair.

This conversation challenges our therapeutic, comfort-obsessed culture. Discover why the church calendar isn't just liturgical tradition‚Äîit's discipleship that keeps Christ's life and work constantly before our eyes. Learn how to practice godly lament, embrace voluntary weakness, and find hope in the wilderness seasons of life.

In This Episode:
-Why low-church Christians should care about Lent and the church calendar
-The difference between fasting for merit versus fasting for remembrance
-How to practice biblical lament with resurrection hope
-Why American Christianity avoids suffering and what we lose because of it
-The hidden grief of Palm Sunday and burned palm branch symbolism
-Balancing community service with personal solitude during Lent

0:00 ‚Äì Introduction
3:07 ‚Äì What is Lent and Why Does it Matter?
8:54 ‚Äì The Experience of Ash Wednesday
15:12 ‚Äì Jesus in the Wilderness and Voluntary Weakness
27:13 ‚Äì Why "Friend of Sinners"?
34:42 ‚Äì Understanding Healthy Christian Lament
42:34 ‚Äì Palm Sunday Triumph and Weeping
51:03 ‚Äì Closing Thoughts

title: The Theocast & Grace Reformed Network Controversy: Interview with Jon Moffit & Doug Van Dorn
description:
Can theological debates destroy Christian unity? In this raw, unfiltered conversation, we sit down with Jon Moffitt @THEOCAST and Doug Van Dorn (@reformedfringe) to discuss one of the more controversial splits in the Reformed world‚Äîand what it reveals about how we handle disagreement in the body of Christ. 

Jon and Doug open up about their journey exploring the spiritual realm, the divine council, and the angel of the Lord‚Äîtopics that sparked fierce opposition within their own theological circles. What began as thoughtful biblical exploration turned into accusations of heresy, demands for public repentance, and ultimately, painful separation from longtime friends and ministry partners.

This isn't just another theology debate. It's a sobering look at how pride, fear, and miscommunication can fracture Christian unity, even among believers who share the same core convictions. Jon and Doug discuss the Grace Reformed Network controversy, the role of Michael Heiser's work in Reformed circles, and why talking about angels and spiritual warfare became so divisive.

We dive deep into questions that matter: How should Christians handle theological disagreements? When does doctrinal clarity become doctrinal gatekeeping? And how do we fight for truth without destroying the very unity Christ prayed for ?

Whether you're Reformed, charismatic, or somewhere in between, this conversation offers crucial lessons about humility, spiritual warfare, and the cost of standing for what you believe. The real enemy isn't the brother who disagrees with you‚Äîit's the one who wants to see the church divided.

Join Joshua Lewis, Michael Miller, Jon Moffitt, and Doug Van Dorn for a conversation about Christian theology, biblical interpretation, spiritual warfare, church unity, and what happens when good men disagree.

0:00 ‚Äì Introduction
7:12 ‚Äì The (Reformed) Fringe podcast
12:43 ‚Äì Heiser, the Divine Council, & pushback 
20:11 ‚Äì Online debates, slander, & controversy
31:05 ‚Äì Strawmanning & accusations of heresy
43:06 ‚Äì Internal concerns & pressure to shut down Fringe
50:04 ‚Äì Email ultimatum
56:02 ‚Äì Board letters, Jon & Doug‚Äôs clarifying response
1:02:24 ‚Äì Doug‚Äôs theology of the Angel of the Lord
1:13:35 ‚Äì How GRN handled Doug‚Äôs old paper & calls for due process
1:19:23 ‚Äì Reflections on unity, charity, & spiritual warfare
1:23:28 ‚Äì Closing

title: Peter: Your Guide to Living as an Elect Exile
description:
Feeling Pulled in Every Direction? Grip on the Gospel Slipping? Find Living Hope and Stand Firm in a Hostile Culture with the Apostle Peter!

Joshua Lewis sits down with Marian Jordan Ellis with@ThisRedeemedLife to unpack the life and letters of the Apostle Peter. Explore how his story gives ordinary believers a living hope in an age of deconstruction, culture pressure, and spiritual warfare. Discover how 1 and 2 Peter equip Christians to stand firm in suffering, live as ‚Äúelect exiles‚Äù in a hostile culture, and embrace their identity as a royal priesthood and holy nation. We dive into Peter‚Äôs most difficult passages, address spiritual warfare, and discuss how to confirm our calling and election. 

From impulsive fisherman to faithful apostle, Peter‚Äôs journey is a model for the Christian life!

title: The Untold History Of Women In The Assemblies Of God: Interview With Dr. Joy Qualls
description:
Joshua Lewis sits down with Dr. Joy Qualls‚ÄîPentecostal scholar, Assemblies of God minister, and author to explore the history, theology, and lived experience of women in Pentecostal leadership. From early Scandinavian pietist revivals and Azusa Street to modern Assemblies of God policy, they trace how Pentecostal theology of Holy Spirit empowerment collided with institutional respectability, evangelical politics, and unspoken ‚Äúinvisible fences‚Äù around women‚Äôs roles in church leadership.

Along the way, they unpack stories of forgotten Pentecostal heroines like Rachel Sislo, Amanda Benedict, May Eleanor Fry, and Blanch Elizabeth Britton‚Äîwomen who planted churches, prayed in revival, confronted injustice, and literally died on the road preaching the gospel. They also explore how AG policy has officially affirmed women in ministry since 1935, even while local practice has often lagged behind, creating dissonance for called women in Pentecostal churches.

This episode will challenge both complementarian and egalitarian assumptions. It raises hard questions about ecclesiology, spiritual gifts vs. church offices, spiritual warfare over calling, and how movements lose their prophetic edge when they chase institutional respectability.

This conversation provides historical context, theological categories, and pastoral wisdom for navigating the debate of women in ministry without capitulating to cultural pressure on either side.

title: Fully God, Fully Man: Understanding the Hypostatic Union
description:
Jesus Christ, the Messiah: fully God and fully man. But how did he live as a human submitted to the Father, perform miracles by the Holy Spirit, and choose not to exercise divine prerogatives at will? 

In this episode, we unpack the Chalcedonian Definition of the Hypostatic Union, exploring its historical significance and how it protects against heresy. We explore how this doctrine affects our understanding of Jesus‚Äôs miracles, the Spirit-Empowered Ministry, and the ongoing debate surrounding kenotic heresy. Learn how Jesus, as both God and Man, performed miracles and lived a life of Spirit-Empowered Ministry.

The Chalcedonian definition of hypostatic union states that Jesus Christ is one person in whom two distinct natures‚Äîdivine and human‚Äîare united without confusion, change, division, or separation. Each nature retains its own properties, and both are unified in one "person" or "subsistence" (\(hypostasis\)), meaning Christ is both fully God and fully man, not a mixture of the two.¬†

One person, two natures: Christ is one person (the eternal Son of God), who is both fully divine and fully human.

Without confusion or change: The divine and human natures are not merged into a single new nature. The incarnation did not diminish Christ's divinity; it was not a change from what he was.

Without division or separation: The two natures are not split into two separate individuals or persons. They are held together in one unique person, the Lord Jesus Christ.

Propriety of each nature is preserved: The unique attributes of each nature remain. For example, Christ's divinity is not bloodied, but as a human, he has a body and soul.

One subsistence: The two natures "concur" in a single person and subsistence, a concept that safeguarded against heresies that separated the natures or blended them together.

In this episode, we're diving into some intriguing prophecies surrounding Charlie's Kirk's death, examining them in light of biblical prophecy and solid Christian theology. We'll look at Kim's 2011 word about an "Esther" figure with "big, beautiful eyes" who steps up to bring healing and restoration to a hurting nation‚Äîa description many are now connecting to Erika Kirk's powerful call for forgiveness after her husband's tragic death.

Then there's Charlie Shamp's July 23, 2023, prophecy (shared at Prepare the Way International Church in Phoenix and later on social media), where he talks about a "shot heard around the world" in Arizona that doesn't shut down the church but instead ignites deeper intercession, groaning prayers from the saints, and a fresh outpouring of revival with God's glory coming down like a cloud.

And we'll hear from Mark Driscoll on the spiritual warfare side, with his message pointing out the demonic forces that could be at work and how martyrdom like this might spark real repentance and shine a light on hidden corruption.

As always, we're approaching this with careful scriptural reflection‚Äîtesting everything against God's Word. Tune in as we call balls and strikes on these prophetic words. Are they balls or strikes?

The Religion Business, a seven-part investigative documentary by Nathan Apffel and Chris Ayoub, examines corruption, financial secrecy, and ethical failures in megachurches and prosperity gospel ministries. In this episode, we dig deep into Scripture to explore how the life, death, resurrection, and ascension of Jesus not only purchases our salvation but also secures the Holy Spirit's gifts for the church. 

We‚Äôll navigate the often-contentious debate between Charismatics and Cessationists, examining how both sides can sometimes miss the full picture. We‚Äôll address the Charismatic tendency to detach the gifts from the core message of the gospel, and the Cessationist impulse to preach a ‚Äúgospel‚Äù that sidelines the very gifts Christ gave to His people. Anchored in biblical theology, we‚Äôll consider whether a gospel without the gifts is really the whole gospel at all.

title: Church Is Not For Worship?
description:
What if everything you knew about ‚Äúworship‚Äù in church wasn‚Äôt biblical? Dr. Tom Wadsworth‚Äôs research offers a challenging new perspective on early church gatherings. Listen, consider the evidence, then decide for yourself.

In this episode of Remnant Radio, Joshua Lewis and Michael Rowntree interview Dr. Tom Wadsworth to explore a controversial question: Is our modern understanding of ‚Äúworship‚Äù truly biblical? 

Dr. Wadsworth, a New Testament scholar, argues that what we call ‚Äúworship services‚Äù today is drastically different from the gatherings of the first-century church. Instead of a primarily vertical act of offering praise to God, he proposes that early Christian assemblies focused on mutual edification ‚Äì building up one another through teaching, encouragement, and the practical application of the ‚Äúone anothering‚Äù commands found throughout the New Testament. 

Dr. Wadsworth traces the history of our modern ‚Äúworship‚Äù concept, exploring its roots in the second century and onward, highlighting the influence of Roman Catholic traditions and the evolving understanding of the Lord‚Äôs Supper. He also unpacks the crucial distinction between preaching (proclamation to outsiders) and teaching (discipleship within the community), and challenges the assumption that the early church was simply a new version of the Old Testament temple.

7:26 Origin of Worship Language
12:54 Exploring Vertical Lines of Worship in Scripture
18:50 Are We Over-examining the Differences?
26:38 Redefining Worship
33:06 What Did a New Testament Church Look Like?
37:02 A Matter of Purpose?
44:16 Teaching
50:44 Modern Discipleship Practices

title: Gifted BUT Unsanctified
description:
Can someone operate in real spiritual power and still be in rebellion against God? We‚Äôre exploring the uncomfortable truth about powerful, yet morally compromised, figures in the Bible and the modern charismatic movement.

In this challenging episode of Remnant Radio, we tackle a provocative topic crucial for Christian discernment: ‚ÄúGifted but Unsanctified.‚Äù We‚Äôll take a hard, biblical look at figures like Samson and Balaam ‚Äì individuals who clearly operated in supernatural power and spiritual gifts, yet were deeply flawed and morally compromised. What do their powerful stories tell us about the intersection of spiritual gifts and personal holiness?

We‚Äôll draw crucial lessons for today‚Äôs church, especially concerning Christian leaders and individuals in the charismatic movement who may display prophetic gifts, healing gifts, or other gifts of the Spirit but lack in Christian character. Join us for a candid discussion on discerning true spiritual authority and the imperative of sanctification alongside divine gifting. This episode is vital for anyone interested in charismatic theology, spiritual maturity, and avoiding charismatic excesses.

Many assume that Spirit baptism is a second blessing, separate from salvation‚Äîbut does the Bible really teach that? We walk through 1 Corinthians 12:13, Acts 2, Acts 8, Acts 10‚Äì11, and Acts 19 to ask:

title: Holy Spirit Baptism: What Every Christian NEEDS To Know
description:
Have you ever wondered what the Baptism of the Holy Spirit truly means? Join us as we journey through the Bible to bring clarity to this powerful Christian doctrine, exploring its Old Testament roots and New Testament fulfillment.

In this episode, we unravel the biblical texts that define the Baptism of the Holy Spirit, from Acts of the Apostles to Paul‚Äôs epistles. We‚Äôll tackle the nuances of indwelling vs. empowerment, the significance of Pentecost, and the Old Testament prophecies that foretold the New Covenant outpouring of the Holy Spirit. 

We'll examine:

‚úÖ The core debate: Is the Baptism of the Holy Spirit a subsequent or simultaneous experience with conversion? 
‚úÖ The classical Pentecostal position and their key proof texts from Acts, including the role of tongues and spiritual gifts. 
‚úÖ The prophetic connection between baptism with fire and God‚Äôs judgment or purification. 
‚úÖ A crucial dive into 1 Corinthians 12:13, clarifying the Baptism of the Holy Spirit as a salvific event that unites all believers into Christ‚Äôs body. 
‚úÖ The historical context of Acts 2 and Acts 8 (Jews & Samaritans) versus Acts 10 (Gentiles) and why it matters for our understanding today. 
‚úÖ The significance of the Day of Pentecost and its powerful parallels with Old Testament events, inaugurating the New Covenant. 
‚úÖThe crucial question: Is this just a semantic debate, or does it profoundly impact church unity, the gifts of the Spirit, and how we view fellow believers? (No ‚Äútwo-tiered Christians‚Äù here!) 
‚úÖ Our concise definition of the Baptism of the Holy Spirit from a ‚ÄúRadical Middle‚Äù perspective.

This discussion will equip you to understand this vital theological topic with clarity, charity, and a deeper appreciation for the power of the Holy Spirit in every believer‚Äôs life.

title: God Told Me! ‚Äì When Prophets Refuse Church Leadership
description:
Can Prophets Be Pastored? | Navigating Prophecy and Church Authority in the Charismatic Movement - Ever seen a prophet go rogue, claiming ‚ÄúGod told me!‚Äù to bypass church leaders? We‚Äôre exploring the essential question of prophetic submission and healthy church culture.

In this episode of Remnant Radio, Josh Lewis, Michael Miller, and Michael Rowntree tackle a pressing question facing many charismatic churches today: Can prophetic people submit to local church leadership? Or more provocatively ‚Äî what happens when prophets refuse to be pastored?

Too often, prophets are seen as untouchable figures who ‚Äúhear directly from God‚Äù and use that perceived authority to bypass or even challenge pastoral leadership. We examine this cultural phenomenon in light of Scripture, offering pastoral insight, biblical parameters, and real-life stories from their own churches and ministries.

We explore:
* The dangers of prophetic elitism and spiritual manipulation
* Biblical models of submission to elders and church order
* When prophecy becomes a platform for rebellion
* Historic abuses from movements like Montanism
* The necessity of protocols, testing, and known character
* How churches can cultivate a healthy prophetic culture without quenching the Spirit

If your church operates in the gifts of the Spirit ‚Äî especially prophecy ‚Äî this is a must-watch conversation. You'll walk away with practical wisdom on how to encourage the prophetic while protecting your church from division, doctrinal confusion, and cult-like authoritarianism.

title: Generational Curses: Fact or Fiction? Responding to Alisa Childers
description:
Generational curses‚Ä¶ are they a real thing the Bible talks about or something new? ü§î We‚Äôre jumping into Alisa Childers‚Äô video and getting real about the tough questions.

You might have seen Alisa Childers‚Äô video on generational curses, and we wanted to jump in with a friendly, scriptural response. We fully respect Alisa‚Äôs heart for handling the Bible carefully, and we‚Äôre bringing that same energy to this conversation about generational curses and deliverance ministry.

We‚Äôre going to unpack some of the big questions that came up. Like, do people who need deliverance actually ask for it? Is this whole deliverance thing a new idea, or is it biblical? Did Jesus always make people repent before casting out demons? We‚Äôll also dig into some classic Bible verses that get brought up, like Exodus 20 and Ezekiel 18, and figure out if they‚Äôre describing something or commanding something. Plus, we‚Äôll look at what Neil Anderson and Sam Storms have to say about generational curses, and we‚Äôll even touch on that tricky question: can a Christian actually have a generational curse? 

Our goal here is to help you think through these often-debated topics in a way that‚Äôs solid and biblical. We want you to feel confident in your discernment and have a balanced understanding of generational curses and deliverance ministry, all rooted in the truth of God‚Äôs Word. Come hang out with us as we dive in!

title: Dr. Craig Keener: Facing Fire | Persecution in 1 Peter
description:
1 Peter was written to believers facing unimaginable persecution-from torture and crucifixions to even being burned alive and used as human torches in Nero's gardens. What can we learn from these first century believers?  The book of 1 Peter is a powerful guide for navigating suffering for your faith.

In this episode of Remnant Radio, we sit down with leading New Testament scholar Dr. Craig Keener (@CraigKeenerPhD) to discuss his commentary on 1 Peter and explore its incredibly relevant message for believers today.

Dr. Keener unpacks how the original recipients of 1 Peter were called ‚Äúforeigners‚Äù and ‚Äúresident aliens,‚Äù a term that highlighted their vulnerable status in a hostile world, especially in the face of impending persecution.

We dive into crucial themes directly related to suffering and persecution, including:
-Seeing ourselves as ‚Äúforeigners‚Äù in this world.
-How suffering for Christ became a badge of honor.
-Responding to mistreatment with Christlike love, not retaliation.
-Standing firm against Satan‚Äôs attempts to make us fall away through pressure.

title: Andrew Klavan: How Reading about Murder Led Me to Christ
description:
What happens when a crime novelist steeped in atheism starts asking hard questions about good, evil, and the meaning of life? In this episode of Remnant Radio, @AndrewKlavan ‚Äîbestselling author, Daily Wire host, and former atheist‚Äîreveals how reading some of the darkest literature in Western history unexpectedly paved his road to Christ. From Dostoevsky‚Äôs Crime and Punishment to the disturbing philosophies of the Marquis de Sade, Klavan shares how the reality of evil pointed him toward objective moral truth‚Äîand ultimately, the beauty of the Gospel. This is not your typical testimony; it‚Äôs a mind-bending journey through murder, meaning, and redemption.

We also unpack Klavan‚Äôs latest book, The Kingdom of Cain: Finding God in the Literature of Darkness, where he argues that some of the most haunting stories in art and culture can become unlikely tools of grace. Can Christians engage deeply with stories of depravity without compromising their faith? Is modern Christian art too safe to be spiritually transformative? And why is beauty, even when born from evil, such a powerful witness to truth? This episode is a bold invitation to think more deeply about art, suffering, and the soul. Don‚Äôt miss it.

NOTE: This show addresses darker topics in literature and art. We would not recommend it for children.

title: Before Genesis: The Eternal Covenant That Shapes Everything
description:
What if the Bible‚Äôs story didn‚Äôt start in Genesis, but in eternity past? Discover the eternal covenant between Father and Son that shapes all of Scripture and salvation history. 

In this episode of Remnant Radio, Joshua Lewis sits down with Dr. Ryan McGraw, professor of systematic theology at Greenville Presbyterian Theological Seminary, to unpack the powerful doctrine of Covenant Theology. 

But this isn‚Äôt just about ancient agreements‚Äîit‚Äôs about the eternal plan of salvation crafted before time began. Dr. McGraw lays out the ‚Äúcovenant of redemption,‚Äù the intra-Trinitarian agreement between the Father and the Son to redeem a people through the perfect obedience and atoning death of Christ. This covenant provides the foundation for everything that unfolds in redemptive history‚Äîfrom Adam‚Äôs failure under the covenant of works, to the unfolding covenant of grace that culminates in Christ and continues through the Church.

Together, they trace the storyline of Scripture from Genesis to Revelation, showing how the theme of covenant brings coherence and clarity to God‚Äôs dealings with His people. You‚Äôll hear how the law reveals not just commands, but the very character of God; how the gospel is embedded even in the earliest pages of the Old Testament; and how the biblical distinction between the seed of the woman and the seed of the serpent runs throughout all redemptive history. Whether you‚Äôre new to covenant theology or looking to deepen your theological roots, this episode will help you see that the Bible is not a disjointed anthology‚Äîbut a breathtaking, unified narrative of God‚Äôs eternal purpose in Christ.

02:30 ‚Äì Covenant Theology: A Blessing You Didn‚Äôt Know You Needed

title: When Theologians Turn on Each Other: What Owen vs. Baxter Teaches Us About Christian Division
description:

title: Believing Through Suffering: Faith or Fantasy?
description:
What happens when your healing prayer is an unanswered prayer? Today we‚Äôre tackling the tension between charismatic faith for miracles and embracing biblical suffering. Join us for an honest conversation about Spirit-filled Christianity that survives life‚Äôs deepest trials.

In this episode, we examine a charismatic perspective on Christian suffering, challenging common misconceptions and overly simplistic interpretations that often lead to spiritual harm. While many believers rightly highlight God's promises for healing, provision, and victory, an unbalanced focus can result in guilt, exhaustion, and disillusionment. We address the dangers of assuming suffering can always be avoided through sufficient faith or perfect confession, emphasizing how this mindset inadvertently shifts trust from God‚Äôs faithful character to our own spiritual performance.

Further, we explore the profound theological tension between God's goodness and the existence of suffering, engaging common questions like "Is my suffering punishment from God?" and "Does God notice my pain?" Through biblical examples and scriptural insights, we propose a robust theology of suffering that affirms pain‚Äôs reality without declaring it inherently good. Ultimately, we encourage believers to maintain hope in God's active compassion and supernatural intervention, anchored in the promise of ultimate redemption and comfort. Be sure to like, subscribe, and share to support thoughtful, Spirit-filled conversations!

title: Christian Living in Cancel Culture: Interview with Keith Simon
description:
Are you struggling with how to engage modern culture as a Christian? Feeling like a biblical worldview makes you an outsider in today‚Äôs society? You‚Äôre not alone. As the gap between Christian values and secular culture grows wider, many believers are wrestling with how to maintain their faith without becoming bitter, fearful, or compromising.

In this episode, we‚Äôre joined by Keith Simon, pastor, author and co-host of Ten Minute Bible Talks and @Not_Just_Sunday, to explore biblical responses to cultural Christianity, cancel culture, and the growing hostility toward traditional Christian values. His new book ‚ÄúJoyful Outsiders‚Äù provides a gospel-centered approach to navigating contemporary issues while maintaining both biblical truth and Christian joy.

We‚Äôre exploring topics from Keith's book, including: ‚Ä¢ Biblical cultural engagement vs. culture war Christianity ‚Ä¢ How to respond to secular culture as a Christian ‚Ä¢ Practical ways to share your faith in a post-Christian world ‚Ä¢ Finding your role in God‚Äôs kingdom as a culture-shaper ‚Ä¢ Christian living in hostile environments ‚Ä¢ Gospel-centered responses to cultural issues ‚Ä¢ Biblical wisdom for modern cultural challenges

Keith identifies six biblical models for cultural engagement: the artist, the protestor, the builder, the advisor, the ambassador, and the trainer. Through these Scripture-based examples, we‚Äôll discover how to maintain biblical faithfulness while effectively engaging our post-Christian culture.

Whether you‚Äôre dealing with workplace hostility to Christianity, navigating social media as a believer, or seeking biblical answers to cultural issues, this conversation will equip you with practical wisdom for being a faithful Christian witness in an increasingly secular world.

Join us as we explore how to be culture-changing Christians who maintain both biblical conviction and Christ-like compassion in today‚Äôs challenging cultural landscape.

title: Can Prayer Grow Your Friendship With God?
description:
How do you develop a friendship with God? Discover how prayer evolves from religious duty to intimate relationship as we explore the biblical foundation for knowing God personally.

Join us as we unpack the profound transition from servant to friend of God, examining Jesus‚Äôs revolutionary words in John 15. We'll explore prayer life, spiritual growth, and supernatural encounters that naturally flow from intimate relationship with God. Through scripture-based teaching, learn how the Holy Spirit reveals God‚Äôs plans and purposes within the context of divine friendship.

We'll tackle essential questions about Christian prayer, spiritual intimacy, and experiencing God‚Äôs presence. Using key passages from James 4:8, Philippians 4:6-7, and Ephesians 1:17, we explore how believers can develop deeper communion with God. Whether you‚Äôre new to prayer or seeking to revitalize your spiritual life, this teaching provides practical insights for growing in friendship with God.

Special attention is given to understanding prayer beyond petition, exploring how the peace of God surpasses understanding and how spiritual gifts flow from relationship. For those hungry for authentic Christian living and deeper spiritual encounters, this episode offers biblical wisdom for developing genuine intimacy with God.

title: Does Your Personality Shape Your Calling?
description:
Does your personality influence your calling? You know, those personality tests everyone‚Äôs taking‚Ä¶ can they tell us anything about how God might use us in His kingdom?

This isn‚Äôt just about Myers-Briggs letters or Strengthsfinder results. It‚Äôs about understanding how God uniquely crafted you AND how He calls you. We‚Äôve seen plenty of ministry books trying to crack this code, but what does Scripture actually say about it?

We‚Äôre breaking down: ‚Ä¢ God‚Äôs blueprint for our calling ‚Ä¢ When natural wiring meets divine purpose ‚Ä¢ Biblical keys for discerning your calling ‚Ä¢ Why getting this right changes everything ‚Ä¢ Real talk about personality tests in the church

We'll dive into the modern psychological application of the Munus Triplex‚Äîas seen in the works of theologians like John Frame¬†and Vern Poythress and also the APEST model popularized by Allen Hirsh.

Whether you roll your eyes at personality tests or you‚Äôve got your MBTI in your social media bio, this episode will challenge you to think biblically about God‚Äôs calling on your life. Join us as we navigate this intersection of personality and purpose - no personality quiz required!

title: Truth or Gossip? How to Navigate Allegations in the Church
description:
In some of our recent episodes, we‚Äôve addressed allegations of sin among notable pastors and Christian influencers, sparking an important question: Are we crossing the line into slander or gossip as we address these issues? 

We‚Äôve also observed pastors accused of wrongdoing using their sermons and platforms to label those discussing the allegations as agreeing with the "accuser of the brethren" or as gossipers spreading baseless claims. 

The Bible, indeed, warns against the very real sins of slander and gossip. 

Where is the biblical boundary between speaking truth and engaging in the sins of gossip or slander? How can we discern when we‚Äôre approaching these pitfalls? And how do we guard our hearts and tongues against falling into them?

In this episode, we turn to Scripture‚Äîour ultimate authority‚Äîto guide us in navigating these challenging situations. Together, we‚Äôll explore how to communicate truth in a way that honors God and avoids sin.

title: Speaking in Faith or Happy Lies? Interview With Melissa Dougherty
description:
Join The Remnant Radio as we sit down with Christian apologist and author Melissa Dougherty (@MelissaDougherty) to discuss her new book, Happy Lies: How a Movement You (Probably) Never Heard Of Shaped Our Self-Obsessed World. Melissa will trace the roots of our culture's toxic subjectivity and relentless pursuit of happiness back to an influential 19th-century philosophy called New Thought‚Äîa movement that shaped much of today‚Äôs self-help culture and even infiltrated the church. 

As a former follower of New Thought teachings, Melissa brings a unique perspective, blending her personal journey with biblical insights and a touch of wit. We‚Äôll discuss:

-The hidden dangers of New Thought philosophy and its modern manifestations.
-How the "positive thought" movement hijacks Christian-sounding ideas and burdens believers.
-Why our culture's obsession with self and "fake authenticity" undermines true redemption.
-How the Christian worldview offers a life-giving alternative to the world's Happy Lies.

This episode promises to be eye-opening, equipping you to recognize and respond to deceptive ideologies with truth and grace. Don‚Äôt miss it!

Book: https://a.co/d/f8IwFoS

title: Exploring The Anointing: What Is The Anointing And How Do You Get It?
description:
In this episode of The Remnant Radio, hosts Joshua Lewis, Michael Miller, and Michael Rowntree dive deep into the theology of the anointing. Together, they explore its roots in the Old Testament, its applications in the New Testament, and its varied interpretations within charismatic circles. This episode unpacks significant biblical texts, such as Jesus‚Äô declaration in Luke 4:18 and the use of anointing oil for healing in James 5:14, while examining the historical and theological development of the concept.

Join us as we tackle questions like:

üëâWhat does the Bible mean by ‚Äúanointing‚Äù?
üëâHow did the early church practice anointing in connection with baptism and deliverance?
üëâHow does the charismatic movement interpret and sometimes redefine anointing?

We also discuss practical implications, such as the role of anointing in spiritual gifts and the importance of aligning modern practices with scriptural truth. Drawing from church history, biblical scholarship, and personal ministry experience, this episode provides a nuanced look at one of the most essential and often misunderstood aspects of Christian theology.

If you‚Äôre interested in understanding how anointing relates to the power of the Holy Spirit, the gifts of healing and prophecy, or the life of Jesus as the Anointed One (Acts 10:38), this episode is for you.

Be sure to subscribe for more theological deep dives, as we continue to explore the intersection of history, theology, and the gifts of the Spirit.

title: DEMYSTIFYING THE DEMONIC: Understanding Spiritual Warfare with Dr. Clint Arnold
description:
What did first-century believers actually understand about demonic forces and spiritual warfare? Join The Remnant Radio for an illuminating conversation with Clinton E. Arnold, PhD, Dean and Professor of New Testament at Talbot School of Theology, as we delve into the realities of spiritual warfare. In this episode, we‚Äôll explore themes from Dr. Arnold‚Äôs book Powers of Darkness: Principalities & Powers in Paul‚Äôs Letters, unpacking what the Apostle Paul teaches about demonic forces, supernatural empowerment, and the role of magic in the first century.

Dr. Arnold sheds light on how first-century Greek, Roman, and Jewish beliefs intersect with the biblical worldview, demonstrating that the New Testament portrays principalities and powers as organized, personal beings defeated by Jesus at the cross and ultimately subdued at His return. We'll also discuss the implications for contemporary Christians, including practical guidance for standing firm against spiritual forces of evil.

As both a New Testament scholar and Dean of Talbot School of Theology, Dr. Arnold bridges the gap between academic research and practical application, helping us understand how to engage in spiritual warfare with biblical wisdom and historical insight. Whether you're seeking to better understand the spiritual battle described in Scripture or to engage thoughtfully with the challenges of modern occult practices, this episode is a must-watch for anyone desiring to navigate the unseen with biblical clarity.

Join us for this crucial conversation that brings biblical, scholarly insight to spiritual warfare.

title: The REAL History of Nicaea You Never Knew
description:
In an era of doctrinal confusion and church scandals, many believers are questioning the very foundation of Christian faith. Can the Nicene Creed offer clarity and stability?

In this episode, we dive deep into the history and significance of the Nicene Creed, established at the Council of Nicaea in 325 A.D., which has served as a cornerstone of Christian belief for centuries. We‚Äôll unpack its core affirmations about God, Jesus, and the Holy Spirit, exploring how it provides a resilient framework for faith amid modern challenges.

But why was the Council of Nicaea so pivotal? Is there biblical support for such councils, or do they risk adding human error to Scripture‚Äôs sufficiency? Together, we‚Äôll examine biblical precedents, such as the early church gatherings in Acts 11 and 15, and look at how councils like Nicaea sought to safeguard Christian doctrine and address critical issues facing the church.

From Constantine‚Äôs political influence to Arius's divisive teachings, we‚Äôll trace how the debates and decisions of the Nicene bishops shaped the bedrock of Christian orthodoxy. Join us as we explore the timeless relevance of the Nicene Creed, discovering how it can strengthen and steady us through personal and collective crises of faith.

title: Introduction to Apologetics: Interview with Dr. William Lane Craig
description:
Join us for an exciting conversation with renowned Christian theologian Dr. William Lane Craig, @ReasonableFaithOrg, as we explore his foundational book, Apologetics: An Introduction. Originally published in 1984, this work remains deeply relevant for Christians today. In a world filled with philosophies that challenge the Christian faith, Craig offers a clear, rational defense of two central pillars: the existence of God and the resurrection of Jesus Christ. We‚Äôll dive into how these themes equip believers to stand firm in their faith and respond thoughtfully to critics. 

Dr. William Lane Craig is known for his work in Christian apologetics, philosophy of religion, and his defense of the Kalam Cosmological Argument. He is a professor of philosophy and a leading voice in debates on the existence of God, the resurrection of Jesus, and philosophical atheism. His expertise and contributions make his book Apologetics: An Introduction especially valuable, as it provides historical context and philosophical rigor in defending Christianity, which remains crucial for believers today. His depth of scholarship enriches any discussion of these timeless theological topics.

As Christians, we understand that leaders are human, fallible, and susceptible to sin. Yet, the repeated revelations of moral failures among those who should know better have left many struggling with a profound sense of betrayal. How do we cope with the emotional toll of these scandals? How can we overcome the fatigue that threatens to erode our faith and commitment?

-Simon the Sorcerer: Analyzing Acts 8, where Simon, a magician who astonished people with his sorcery, seeks to buy the Holy Spirit's power from the apostles. What can we learn from his misguided pursuit of spiritual power?

title: What is the Law & Gospel Distinction? Crossover with Theocast

The Law of God: As the perfect standard for all mankind, the Law is good, beautiful, and faultless. It exposes the sinfulness of both saints and sinners, compelling them to seek forgiveness and everlasting life outside of themselves.

The Gospel (Good News): The Law of God has been perfectly fulfilled in Jesus. Those who place their faith in Him receive His spotless record. While the Law says ‚Äúdo,‚Äù the Gospel says ‚Äúdone.‚Äù Our goal is to remind God‚Äôs people to rest in Jesus‚Äô finished work.

Join us for an insightful discussion on how understanding the Law and Gospel distinction can transform your faith and bring clarity to your Christian walk.

title: Did Brandon Biggs Prophesy the Trump Assassination Attempt?
description:
The July 13 assassination attempt on former President Trump's life made headlines across the world. Did God forewarn of this event with a prophetic message? We'll take a closer look at a YouTube video from March 14 this year, where Brandon Biggs gave a prophecy that many believe foreshadowed this shocking event. We'll analyze Brandon's prophecy and discuss whether he hit the mark, exploring the implications for believers and the broader Christian community.

In this episode, we critically examine a prophecy by Brandon Biggs, who claimed an attempt on President Trump's life would be made. According to Biggs, the attempt would fail, but Trump would be struck near the ear, fall to his knees, and experience a profound spiritual awakening. This prophecy, given months before the incident, has sparked significant debate about Biggs' legitimacy as a prophet.

We discuss the importance of testing prophets and prophecies. As charismatics, we believe in the gift of prophecy but emphasize the biblical mandate to "test everything; hold fast what is good" (1 Thessalonians 5:21). We analyze Biggs' character, doctrine, and track record, scrutinizing his predictions in light of Scripture. Our goal is not to dismiss prophecy but to ensure it aligns with biblical truth and edifies the Church.

In this episode, we explore why rigorous testing of prophetic words is crucial. We reference key scriptures like Deuteronomy 13:1-5 and Matthew 7:15-23, which warn about false prophets who may deliver accurate predictions but lead people astray through false doctrines and unbiblical practices. We also emphasize the need to evaluate prophets based on their fruit, doctrine, and track record, as outlined in Matthew 7:15-20 and Deuteronomy 18:20-22.

Join us as we navigate the complex landscape of modern prophecy, seeking to uphold the integrity of the charismatic movement while guarding against deception. Whether you're a charismatic, cessationist, or somewhere in between, The Remnant Radio is committed to providing thoughtful, balanced, and biblically grounded discussions on the gifts of the Spirit and contemporary Christian issues.

The Remnant Radio is hosted by Joshua Lewis, pastor of King's Fellowship Church in Ada, Oklahoma, along with his co-hosts Michael Miller, pastor of Reclamation Church Denver, and Michael Rowntree, leader of Convergence OKC. Together, they explore the dynamic and often controversial world of charismatic Christianity.

In their book, Wright and Bird explore the critical question of how Christians should engage with politics. Should we withdraw to maintain our prophetic voice, or should we actively participate to influence political systems? Combining political theology, biblical insights, and church history, "Jesus and the Powers" argues for a kingdom-oriented approach to politics. They delve into the relevance of this approach to current events, including the Russian-Ukraine conflict, China-Taiwan tensions, and political turmoil in the USA, UK, and Australia.

Tune in to learn how Christians can navigate and engage with politics in a way that aligns with Jesus's kingdom and contributes to the common good.

title: Clergy Loyal to the Crown? Interview with Dr. Gregg Frazer
description:
We're exploring a side of the American Revolution that often gets overlooked. In this episode, we sit down with Dr. Gregg Frazer to discuss his book God against the Revolution: The Loyalist Clergy's Case against the American Revolution.

Romans 13:1 says, "Let everyone be subject to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God." This biblical principle of obeying authority is at the heart of Frazer's book. 

Frazer‚Äôs work offers the first comprehensive account of the political thought of the American Loyalists ‚Äì the roughly one-third of the population who opposed independence. While we know much about the Patriots, what about those who loved their land but didn't support breaking away from Britain? Frazer digs into the biblical, philosophical, and legal arguments made by Loyalist ministers in their writings, pamphlets, and sermons. These clergymen were far from being mere apologists for British rule; they criticized its excesses while arguing for adherence to English law and authority.

In our interview, we'll explore how these Loyalist ministers' perspectives provide an interesting counterpoint to the Patriots' fight for liberty, equality, and representation. Frazer raises challenging questions about the rationality and legitimacy of the Patriots' actions and their impacts on freedom of religion, expression, and due process. 

So how should we examine the Bible's command to submit to authority? This discussion is not only an interesting addition to our understanding of American political thought but also a timely reflection on the political dynamics of our own era.

Join us as we delve into this nuanced and often forgotten perspective on the American Revolution. 

***
Gregg L. Frazer is Dean, John P. Stead School of Humanities, and Professor of History & Political Studies at The Master‚Äôs University in Santa Clarita, California. He‚Äôs the author of The Religious Beliefs of America's Founders: Reason, Revelation, and Revolution (University Press of Kansas). Gregg is a deacon at Grace Community Church in Sun Valley, California.

title: Biblical Diviners & Prophets? Interview with Dr. Ben Witherington III
description:
Explore biblical prophecy with esteemed biblical scholar Dr. Ben Witherington III as he discusses his book, "Jesus the Seer: The Progress of Prophecy." Jesus the Seer explores the profound role of prophecy in both the Old and New Testaments and how it all points to the life and ministry of Jesus Christ.

Dr. Witherington unpacks the historical and theological contexts of prophecy, shedding light on its significance in the ancient Near East and Greco-Roman world. He explains how ancient cultures relied on diviners to interpret signs from nature, while court prophets served kings with their insights. In contrast, the Israelites transitioned from these practices as Yahweh‚Äôs prophets rose to prominence, delivering divine messages directly from God. Meanwhile, priests took on roles that involved interpreting God‚Äôs will through sacred objects such as the Urim and thummim, effectively replacing the diviners of surrounding nations.

Our conversation examines the complexities of distinguishing true prophecy from false, the role of court prophets, and the fascinating interplay between prophetic and wisdom literature. Dr. Witherington also shares his perspective on how the Holy Spirit operates differently in the New Covenant era, emphasizing the importance of discernment in contemporary prophetic practice.

Don't miss this thought-provoking discussion that not only enriches our understanding of biblical prophecy but also points us back to the central figure of our faith‚ÄîJesus Christ. Whether you're a pastor, teacher, or theology enthusiast, this episode is packed with valuable insights that will deepen your appreciation for the prophetic traditions of the Bible.

title: Examining Mysticism in Today's Culture
description:
Join us for our discussion with theologian Andrew Root on his book The Church in An Age of Secular Mysticism. In a world flooded with spiritualities promising personal transformation, Root sheds light on the differences between these mysticisms and authentic Christian transformation. We'll explore the dangers of following or adapting these reigning mysticisms and learn why the self has become so important yet so burdened with guilt--and how we should think about both. Root will present a better way--even a mysticism--centered on the theology of the cross that pastors and leaders can use to form their own imaginations and practices. 

For secular mysticism explained and how a Christian should approach mysticism, tune in to this episode of The Remnant Radio!

Andrew Root (PhD, Princeton Theological Seminary) is the Olson Baalson Professor of Youth and Family Ministry at at Luther Seminary in St. Paul, MN.

title: Christians Talk Psychedelics: Ayahuasca ü§îüåøüôèüèº
description:
Ever heard of Ayahuasca? Ayahusaca is a sacred plant medicine used in ceremonies by indigenous communities in the Amazon rainforest. And there are some crazy stories out there from people reporting spiritual experiences after taking Ayahuasca. You can find numerous testimonies of atheists and drug addicts experiencing God and coming to Christ after this experience - descriptions of another dimension that is 'more real than reality'. In recent years, Ayahuasca has gained popularity in Western cultures, leading to the rise of Ayahuasca tourism and retreats - and even churches promoting its spiritual benefits. But is this something Christians should be experiencing? If the substance is bringing people to Christ, should churches be exploring it? Or is this something we should mark and stay away?

Join us as we discuss the moral and biblical implications of Ayahuasca.

Did Jesus go to Hell? Did Jesus go to Sheol? The doctrine of Christ‚Äôs ‚Äúdescent‚Äù is confessed in the Apostles‚Äôs and Athanasian Creeds and celebrated by Eastern and Roman Catholic churches, but evangelical churches rarely give it much attention. Even where the Apostles‚Äôs Creed is recited many evangelicals leave out the clause, ‚Äúhe descended into hell/the dead.‚Äù So just what is the doctrine of Jesus descending to the dead? Did Jesus go to hell for 3 days?

In this episode, we'll interview Matt Emerson and discuss his book "He Descended to the Dead": An Evangelical Theology of Holy Saturday, winner of a 2019 TGC book award. From biblical foundations to historical context and pastoral implications, we'll discuss it all with Matt.

Book: https://a.co/d/4UfqbYj

Matt Emerson (Ph.D., Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary ) serves as Co-Provost and Dean of Theology, Arts, & Humanities at Oklahoma Baptist University. He also serves on the Board of Directors for the Center for Baptist Renewal. His areas of interest include biblical theology, canonical interpretation, theological method, and Baptist theology.

title: What Makes the Church "The Church"? Ecclesiology
description:
In this episode, we'll meet with theologian Veli-Matti K√§rkk√§inen and discuss his book "An Introduction to Ecclesiology." 

We'll chat with K√§rkk√§inen about the theological questions he poses about ecclesiology (the doctrine of the church). What is the church, and why are there so many diverse expressions of it? What are the major traditions and why do we have different traditions if we have one universal church? K√§rkk√§inen will share his thoughts about the major traditions, global perspectives, and key elements of the church's mission, governance, worship, and more.

Veli-Matti K√§rkk√§inen (Dr.Theol.Habil., University of Helsinki) is professor of systematic theology at Fuller Theological Seminary in Pasadena, California, and docent of ecumenics at the University of Helsinki. He is ordained by the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America and is also an expert on Pentecostal/charismatic movements. He has served as visiting professor in various schools around the world and has participated in numerous international theological, missiological, and interfaith consultations. His many books include The Trinity: Global Perspectives, An Introduction to the Theology of Religions, and the five-volume series A Constructive Christian Theology for the Pluralistic World.

title: Jewish-Christian Unity in the Early Church: Interview with R.L. Solberg
description:
Join us for an eye-opening interview with R.L. Solberg, author of "Divergence: Examining Jewish-Christian Relations in the Early Church." R. L. Solberg is an author, apologist, and professor of theology. He runs an apologetics/teaching ministry called Defending the Biblical Roots of Christianity ( @TheBiblicalRoots ). 

In his book, Solberg sheds light on a crucial yet often overlooked aspect of history. Discover the untold truth behind Jewish-Christian relations and the evolution of attitudes toward the Jewish people from the New Testament era to the writings of the early Church Fathers to the council of Nicaea in AD 325. Spoiler alert: It's not what you might think.

With 100% of the profits donated to fight anti-Semitism worldwide, "Divergence" offers a timely message on promoting peace and unity.

title: End Times Triumph: Interview with Matt Chandler ‚úùÔ∏èüìñ
description:
Join us for a discussion with Matt Chandler, pastor and author of several books including his newest, The Overcomers. 

In this episode of Remnant Radio, Chandler unpacks the profound insights of Revelation, shedding light on its significance for our lives today. We'll discuss how Revelation serves as a beacon of encouragement from God, inviting us to embrace His purpose in the midst of life's chaos.

Chandler will share the unique perspective Revelation offers, revealing God's redemptive work amidst the messiness of our world. Through the lens of Revelation, we are reminded of our identity as uniquely created children of God, called to play a vital role in His unfolding plan.

Discover how Revelation challenges us to become overcomer‚Äîbelievers propelled by scriptural truths, empowered by the work of Jesus, and encouraged by the faithful witnesses who have gone before us. Gain a deeper understanding of our place in God's kingdom and the significance of our faith journey.

#remnantradio #bookofrevelation #endtimes #eschatology

title: Slain in the Spirit: Hoax or Real?
description:
Curious about being "slain in the Spirit" in the church? Is it fake or an authentic Holy Spirit experience? We'll explore the biblical roots of this phenomenon and address pressing questions: Is it truly grounded in Scripture or a modern, emotion-mixed practice? Is it linked to New Age practices infiltrating the church?

We'll provide a thorough biblical examination, shedding light on the complexities and controversies surrounding the occurrence. Join us for a balanced, theologically-focused discussion on slain in the spirit!

title: Missing Messiah in the Masoretic? ‚úùÔ∏èüìñ
description:
Our guest, S. Douglas Woodward, an author of twenty books on Christian theology and eschatology, will guide us through the intriguing insights of his latest book.

Discover how the Septuigant, rooted in ancient Hebrew scripture, predates the Masoretic Text by centuries. Delve into the mysteries of Messianic prophecies and the alterations made by second-century rabbis. Woodward will examine the transmission of the Old Testament, the New Testament's faithful reflection of original authors, and the defense of the Bible through the Septuagint. Don't miss out on this exploration into the ancient Greek Bible's revelations about the foundational truths of Christianity.

Hill, professor emeritus with @ReformedSeminary, takes us on a journey through Jewish texts, the New Testament, and early Christian writings up to the mid-third century A.D. as we discuss his groundbreaking book, "Regnum Caelorum."

title: Exposing Freemasons: Secret Vows and Oaths - Interview with Ken Fish
description:
Join us for an interview with Ken Fish (@KenFishEnglish) as we delve into the realms of Freemasonry. In Remnant Radio's most-watched video with more than half a million views, we exposed aspects of this secretive organization. We discussed the demonic oppression that Ken often encounters when ministering to freemasons or descendants of freemasons. We also discussed demonic curses, generational curses, and how to walk in biblical freedom from these cult practices. 

Catch the first episode here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ePVAbKZWra8

In this show, we welcome Ken Fish back for further discussion. We'll unravel lesser-known forms of Freemasonry, examine the existence of founder spirits and master spirits‚Äîrarely discussed topics, as well as review the often-overlooked issue of sexual abuse, embedded within the rituals of higher-level masonic lodges.

üëâ33 Degrees of Deception:

title: A Theology of Cursing & Blessing üìñüîçPart 2
description:
Join us for our continued exploration into blessings and curses in the Bible. In Part 1, we delved into the essence of blessings, unraveling the Biblical ways blessings work and how they're bestowed. If you missed it, catch up here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jYsUFjrHECI.

In Part 2, we shift our focus to curses.ü§î What are curses, and how do they manifest throughout Scripture? Are generational curses Biblical? Discover the Biblical perspective on how to break a curse.

Curses:
-Utterance intended to invoke supernatural power to cause harm to something or someone
-Offensive word or phrase used to express anger or annoyance
-Divine judgment placed on a sinful person for sinful actions or punishment or misfortune
-Generational curse

title: Ministry in Mozambique: Interview with Heidi Baker
description:
Join us for our interview with Christian missionary Heidi Baker (@heidibakerministries6800) as she discusses her Christian missions ministry in Mozambique, Africa! Heidi Baker is a Christian missionary, speaker, and writer who is the CEO of Iris Global, a Christian humanitarian organization. She and her husband Rolland Baker founded Iris Global in 1980 and have been serving in various countries, especially in Mozambique, where they care for thousands of orphaned and abandoned children. She has a PhD in systematic theology from King's College London and has written several books on Christian spirituality.

#remnantradio #christianmissionaries #christianmissionary #christianmissions

title: A Theology of Cursing & Blessing üìñüîçPart 1
description:
What does the Bible say about blessings and curses? What are they? How do they work?

What does it look like to bless?
-Blessings bestowed by God to humanity for covenantal faithfulness
-Delegated blessings bestowed by God to human offices, prophets, priests, kings
-Blessings bestowed by patriarchal heads of households
-Blessings that are worship or praise
-Unconditional Gospel blessings

The Remnant Radio hosts unravel the mysteries surrounding blessings and curses in the Bible and examine the biblical insights and verses about them. Don't miss this episode that promises to deepen your understanding of these spiritual dynamics.

title: Is God a Vindictive Bully? ü§î Interview with Paul Copan
description:
Join us for an insightful interview with Paul Copan as we dive into his book "Is God a Vindictive Bully?" Unravel the complexities surrounding critics' accusations of genocide, racism, and violence in the Old Testament. Copan challenges imbalanced teachings, highlighting the kindness, patience, and compassion of God in the Old Testament while demonstrating the divine severity revealed by Jesus in the New Testament. Whether you're seeking clarity on challenging biblical passages or interested in the broader theological context, this interview is a must-watch.

Paul Copan is a Christian theologian, analytic philosopher, apologist, and author. He is currently a professor at the Palm Beach Atlantic University and holds the endowed Pledger Family Chair of Philosophy and Ethics1 2. He has written and edited over 40 books in the area of philosophy of religion, apologetics, theology, and ethics in the Bible.

title: Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #7: With Guest Dr. Craig Keener
description:
We're honored to have Dr. Craig Keener with us to provide his insights on the arguments and points raised by the Cessationist film makers. We will continue to examine the continuationist vs cessationist debate on whether the gifts of the Spirit are for today as we review the Cessationist film.

Dr. Craig S. Keener is F. M. and Ada Thompson Professor of Biblical Studies at Asbury Theological Seminary. He is the author of 37 books with 1.4 million copies in circulation. His books have won 13 national and international awards, including six from Christianity Today.

Dr. Keener has authored roughly 100 academic articles, seven booklets, and roughly 200 popular-level articles. His ‚ÄúThe IVP Bible Background Commentary: New Testament,‚Äù which provides cultural background for each passage of the New Testament, has alone sold more than half a million copies. He has written commentaries on Matthew, Romans, 1-2 Corinthians, Galatians, 1 Peter, Revelation, John (1,600 pages), and Acts (4,500 pages). His other books include a two-volume work on miracles and works about the Spirit, ethnic reconciliation, women in ministry, divorce, and various other topics. His publishers include Baker Academic, Cambridge, Eerdmans, InterVarsity and Zondervan. He is currently writing an academic commentary on Mark for T&T Clark.

Dr. Keener is the New Testament editor for the NIV Cultural Backgrounds Study Bible, which won the International Book Award for Christianity as well as Bible of the Year for the Christian Book Awards. In 2020, Dr. Keener was president of the Evangelical Theological Society. He is former editor of the Bulletin for Biblical Research and former program chair for the Institute for Biblical Research. Craig is married to Dr. M√©dine Moussounga Keener, who was a refugee in her home country of Congo for 18 months; her experience and their romance appears in ‚ÄúImpossible Love‚Äù (Chosen, 2016). 

Tune in for an engaging discussion with one of today's leading theologians!

For our Cessationist Study Guide, subscribe to our newsletter at www.theremnantradio.com. 

#remnantradio #cessationist #cessationistfilm #cessationism #charismatic #giftsofthespirit 

Dr. Keener's YouTube Channel:  @CraigKeenerPhD

title: Rethinking Luke & Acts: Interview with Michael Bird
description:
Ever wondered what the books of Luke and Acts teach us about God, Jesus, and the early church? How do they relate to each other, and what do they mean for us today? Michael Bird dives deep into these questions, providing an accessible and compelling introduction to the narrative of Luke-Acts in his book: A Bird's-Eye View of Luke and Acts: Context, Story, and Themes. We'll chat with Michael and discuss his insights.

In his book, Bird unfolds the cohesive narrative about Jesus, the Church, and the mission of God, offering insights with implications for our lives today. Situating both books in their historical and literary context, Bird explores their central theological themes and concludes with reflections on their relevance for contemporary social issues. 

Don't miss this insightful conversation that goes beyond the pages and brings ancient wisdom into our modern world.

Michael Bird's YouTube Channel: @earlychristianhistorywithm8684

title: Is the King James Version Too Archaic? Mark Ward Shares Study Results
description:
In this episode, we'll wade into the King James Bible only debate (versus other translations). We'll interview Mark Ward on his KJV Bible Study Project.

Mark Ward (@wardonwords) asserts that the difficulties for vital understanding caused by the archaism of the King James Version are more important than the textual differences valued by KJV-only proponents. To evaluate his assertion, he conducted the King James Bible Study Project, a national phone survey of 100 pastors who preach and teach King James Bible only that ran from November 2022 through April 2023. 

We'll talk with Mark and hear the results of his study project.

title: The Shepherd of Hermas Explained With Dr. Michael Svigel
description:
Delve deep into the complexities and nuances of one of early Christianity's most enigmatic works: The Shepherd of Hermas. We'll journey through this ancient text of the Shepherd of Hermas with our guest Dr. Michael Svigel, who addresses a range of thought-provoking questions:

Historical Authenticity: Explore whether the Shepherd of Hermas we have today is historically accurate and reflects the original work.

Authorship: Uncover insights into whether this text was a collective effort or the singular vision of one author.

Literary Genre: Understand the unique blend of genres that define the Shepherd of Hermas, from visionary revelation to moral instruction.

Prophetic or Satirical? Debate the true nature of Hermas's experiences ‚Äì were they genuine prophetic visions or satirical allegories?

Early Church Perspectives: Learn how early Church Fathers like Irenaeus, Clement, and Tertullian viewed this text, from its edifying qualities to its scriptural authority.

Scriptural Connections: Discover the intriguing ways the Shepherd of Hermas interweaves Biblical themes without direct quotations.

Christian or Jewish Identity: Investigate the Christological aspects within the text and its alignment with early Christian beliefs.

Hermas's Spiritual Journey: Follow Hermas's evolution from a struggling believer to a mature Christian through the narrative's structure of Visions, Mandates, and Similitudes.

Visionary Imagery & Symbolism: Delve into the vivid depictions of spiritual realms and their implications for understanding early Christian eschatology and ethics.

Dr. Svigel's comprehensive analysis illuminates the Shepherd of Hermas's role in early Christian thought, its distinctive literary style, and its enduring relevance in understanding the development of Christian doctrine and practice. Don't miss this engaging episode that brings new depth to our understanding of early Christian literature and its impact on the church's formation.

title: The 12 Patriarchs and the Dead Sea Scrolls: Interview with Ken Johnson üìú
description:
We interviewed Ken Johnson with BibleFacts.org (@biblefactsorg). Talmud teaches that the ancient patriarchs were all prophets, and that each one of them left testaments for their descendants to read. These contain commands for their children, moral lessons, and prophecy. This legend is not only repeated among the Essene community, but fragments of twenty such records have been found in the Dead Sea scrolls.

Ken‚Äôs book, Ancient Testaments of the Patriarchs: Autobiographies from the Dead Sea Scrolls, shares the testaments of Enos (Adam‚Äôs grandson), Enoch, Lamech (Noah‚Äôs father), Noah, Abraham, Jacob, Levi, Judah, Naphtali, Joseph, Benjamin, Kohath (son of Levi, and father of Amram), Amram (father of Moses, Aaron, and Miriam), and Aaron. In addition, he addresses many extra-biblical prophecies of the Messiah, including Aaron‚Äôs warning about the Messiah's First Coming.

We'll wade into the Messianic prophecies debate and discuss Messianic prophecies fulfilled by Jesus. We'll also discuss Ancient patriarchs in the Bible, look at who are the ancient patriarchs and examine the testaments of the ancient patriarchs.

#remnantradio #deadseascrolls #messianicjudaism #biblefacts #talmud

title: How Do We Process the Allegations Against Mike Bickle?
description:
How Do We Process the Allegations Against Mike Bickle?

In today's episode of The Remnant Radio, we grapple with the distressing allegations levied against Mike Bickle, the leader of the International House of Prayer. Our hearts are heavy, and our spirits are burdened with empathy and pain as we discuss the serious alleged claims of sexual abuse brought forth by former IHOP staff members Dwayne Roberts, Brian Kim, and Wes Martin. In the midst of this storm, we find it crucial to clarify our intent: we are not live streaming to declare "guilty" or "not guilty." Our aim is to aid our listeners in processing these events with discernment and to remind our audience of the biblical standards that must be upheld, irrespective of the individuals involved.

With the gravity that such allegations command, we will review the public statement and the subsequent actions of the IHOP executive team, including their recent appointment of a law firm to conduct an independent investigation. As we navigate these challenging discussions, we do so with utmost respect for all parties, emphasizing the need for a fair and just process that honors the truth and the well-being of the victims. We invite you to join us in a time of reflection, prayer, and engagement with the Word, as we seek wisdom and guidance on how to uphold the honor and integrity of the Church in every circumstance.

title: Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #6
description:
Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #6 | Cessationist Movie Review

In this episode of The Remnant Radio, your theology podcast, we bring an insightful response to cessationist views and responding to the Cessationist film, while also exploring charismatic theology.

Section One: Prophecy's Ambiguity
Is prophecy always clear, exact, and infallible? We challenge this cessationist belief by examining biblical passages like Numbers 12, 1 Samuel 3, and Jeremiah 32. Discover why we argue that God's communication sometimes requires discernment and isn't always straightforward.

Section Two: Modern Prophecy and Discernment
With the rise of false prophets on digital platforms, like YouTube, we'll discuss the importance of heightened discernment and self-regulation in the charismatic community. Key scriptures like Deuteronomy 13 and 18 will shed light on the ethical implications of false prophecy and the grace needed for well-intentioned prophets who make mistakes.

Section Three: Democratization of Prophetic Roles
We'll explore the transformation of prophetic roles from the Old to the New Testament. Our hosts suggest that a democratization has occurred, opening the gift of prophecy to all believers. This inclusivity highlights the importance of discernment. While the prophetic function remains consistent, modern prophetic messages require distinct methods of discernment and testing.

Don't miss this comprehensive episode where we dismantle cessationist arguments, unravel the complexities of charismatic theology, and find the balance between upholding the integrity of Scripture and valuing spiritual gifts. Join us today as theology meets real-world application! 

For our Cessationist study guide, subscribe to our newsletter: www.TheRemnantRadio.com.

title: What is Torahism? Are Christians Required to Keep the Law of Moses? R.L. Solberg Interview
description:
Join The Remnant Radio for a theological discussion with R.L. Solberg and his book addressing the questions: Are Christians required to keep the Law of Moses? Are Christians required to keep the Ten Commandments? Was Jesus divine?

R. L. Solberg is an author, apologist, and professor of theology. He runs an apologetics/teaching ministry called Defending the Biblical Roots of Christianity (@TheBiblicalRoots) and is a leading Christian apologist against Torahism (aka Hebrew Roots, Torah-observant Christianity), which is a teaching that followers of Jesus are required to keep the Old Testament Law. He has been pursuing theology, apologetics, and philosophy formally and informally for more than two decades. 

We'll hear him discuss Torahism and other critical questions related to the Jewish roots of the Christian faith.

#remnantradio #torahism #hebrewroots

description:
Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #5: With Guest Dr. Sam Storms | Cessationist Movie Review

üî• The Remnant Radio, your trusted theology podcast, is back with the fifth video in our series dedicated to debunking the claims made in the controversial Cessationist documentary. Dive deep with us into charismatic theology as we challenge cessationist assertions and set the historical record straight!

In this live-stream, we're excited to have Dr. Sam Storms joining us for a comprehensive four part response:

The History of Speaking in Tongues & Cessationism Explained: Addressing claims by Phil Johnson and Nathan Busenitz, who suggest the gift of tongues made a sudden resurgence in the 20th century. We'll explore historical evidence to provide a counter-narrative to their cessationist viewpoint.

Charismatic Leaders & Their Legacy ‚Äì Cessationism Exposed: We respond to Phil Johnson and Justin Peters' overarching criticisms, which indicate that the entire Charismatic movement is tainted due to the moral failings of a few leaders.

Reformed Charismatic Leaders & The Sufficiency of Scripture ‚Äì Cessationist Refuted: With insights from Dr. Sam Storms, we'll tackle Sam Waldron and Josh Buice's arguments. They suggest figures like Wayne Grudem, John Piper, and Dr. Storms himself might compromise the sufficiency of scripture due to their Charismatic leanings.

Modern Worship & The Charismatic Influence ‚Äì Cessationism Refuted: Responding to Scott Aniol's perspective, we'll make a case that feeling the spirit's presence during worship is not just a Charismatic expectation but a biblical one.

Engage with this essential episode of The Remnant Radio as we navigate the nuances of charismatic theology and offer responses to prominent cessationist critiques. title: Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #4 | Cessationist Movie Review
description:
Welcome back to The Remnant Radio, your go-to Theology Podcast for deep dives into Charismatic Theology. In this fourth installment of "Responding To The Cessationist Documentary," we delve deeper into the layers of contradiction and the problematic historical understandings presented in the Cessationist film.

üîç Section 1: Here, we tackle the confusing narratives around the timeline of miracles. Bill Vandoodewaard's statements clash head-on with what Phill Johnson, Josh Boice, and Nathan Busenitz have claimed earlier in the Cessationist documentary. The constant contradictions among cessationist views leave us wondering: Do they even understand their own proposed timeline? Join us as Remnant Radio exposes these discrepancies, debunking cessationist theories one by one.

üî• Section 2: We address Chad Vegas's incendiary claims that hinge on a flawed understanding of Protestantism. Claiming that "to believe in sola scriptura is to be a cessationist" and associating charismatic beliefs with non-Protestant views are not just oversimplifications but fundamentally incorrect. With a deep dive into church history, Remnant Radio swiftly debunks these claims by shedding light on the rich history of prophetic, apostolic, and healing gifts that were evident among the Scottish Presbyterians such as George Wishart, John Davidson, John Knox, John Welsh, Robert Bruce, and Samuel Rutherford. And yes, we even bring Charles Spurgeon into the mix!

Engage with us as we continue our series "Responding to the Cessationist Documentary - Part 4" and explore the intricate nuances of Charismatic Theology. If you've ever pondered cessationism explained or sought a response to cessationist claims, this is the place to be. Join us as we refute and expose cessationism, piece by piece.

For our Cessationist study guide, subscribe to our newsletter at www.theremnantradio.com.

4:45 - Contradictory Time Lines!
25:55 - Charismatics Are Not Protestant
33:37 - History Of The Gifts In Protestantism
