title: The Rule of King Jesus Seen In Miracles #miracles #miraculous #cessationism #cessationist #remnant
description:
The Rule of King Jesus Seen In Miracles #miracles #miraculous #cessationism #cessationist #remnant

"But, once again, the point Michael made earlier was that it wasn't just the apostles who were working miracles. You've got the 72 who were sent out to heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, cast out demons, and even raise the dead. I mean, you've got these reports coming back from the disciples saying, 'Hey, we did these things in your name.'

The other thing Michael was attaching to this is that it wasn't just the messenger being affirmed. Primarily, it was the message itself that was being affirmed. The message being that the kingdom of God is at hand, which simply means the rule or reign of King Jesus is at hand.

So, what does it look like for King Jesus to rule and reign? Well, it looks like demons getting cast out. It looks like the sick getting healed, lepers being cleansed, the blind regaining their sight, and even the dead being raised. These are all normative things when God expresses His rule and reign here on Earth."

title: Unlocking Miracles Through The Power of Faith #miracles #miraculous #remnantradio #cessationist
description:
Unlocking Miracles Through The Power of Faith #miracles #miraculous #remnantradio #cessationist

What if everyone in America started believing that God can do these things and passionately pursued Jesus? I bet we'd see more happening. I also think that in the third world, where people have to rely on God for miracles and don't have scholars telling them that God no longer gives these kinds of gifts, they're witnessing it happening like crazy, and it's well-documented. I would wager that faith is a significant component of that."

title: Responding To The Hebrews 2:2-4 Cessationist Argument
description:
Responding To The Hebrews 2:2-4 Cessationist Argument

One of the frequently cited texts supporting cessationism is Hebrews 2:3‚Äì4, where the author emphasizes the significance of the gospel message being confirmed by three stages. First, Jesus declared it with divine authority. Second, eyewitnesses testified to its truth through their experiences with Jesus. Finally, God affirmed it with signs, wonders, and gifts of the Holy Spirit.

However, some debate whether this passage implies the cessation of such manifestations after the apostolic era. John MacArthur contends that these miracles were primarily for validating the message of Christ and the apostles. He interprets the past tense in "it was attested" to mean that these gifts were for the first-generation apostles alone. Similarly, Pastor Tom Pennington suggests that Hebrews 2 indicates that miraculous manifestations were foundational and no longer the norm in the present day. John MacArthur believes that this passage ‚Äúconfirms that the validation of the prophets was the chief purpose for biblical miracles.‚Äù He argues yet again that ‚Äúwe see Scripture attesting that signs, wonders, miracles, and miraculous gifts were God‚Äôs confirmation of the message of Christ and His apostles (‚Äòthose who heard‚Äô).‚Äù In like manner, Pastor Tom Pennington of Countryside Bible Church speaks of Hebrews 2 and says, "The writer of Hebrews, writing just before he says, the Lord spoke this gospel. It was confirmed to us by those who heard, meaning the Apostles, and the Apostles were allowed to work signs and miracles to confirm that message. And so even the writer of Hebrews, writing under the auspices of the Apostles, says, 'I'm not working miracles; that's not happening now. The writer of Hebrews is looking back and saying those things were foundational; that's not the norm anymore."

In response, we present seven counterarguments based on Dr. Sam Storm's book "Understanding Spiritual Gifts."

1) Conceding that validating prophets was a primary purpose of biblical miracles doesn't exclude other purposes documented in the New Testament. Therefore, miracles should be used to display God's compassion, God's glory, and should be used evangelistically.

2) The author of Hebrews doesn't limit the text to apostles; the term "apostle" doesn't even appear. "Those who heard" can encompass more than the Twelve. There is no reason to assume Hebrews is only speaking of Apostles.

3) The text doesn't specify what or whom God "bore witness" to through signs and wonders. The focus is probably "the great salvation." God is not bearing witness to the Apostles' authority as worthy messengers because the text says nothing about the Apostles.

4) The cessationist claims that God "bore witness" (past tense) meaning that the author of Hebrews no longer believed that God was "bearing witness" to miracles in his day. The word "bore witness" in Greek is in the present tense, suggesting ongoing confirmation. Therefore, it is likely that the miracles are still active.

5) The passage doesn't rule out God attesting to the gospel through supernatural displays of power today; it only suggests that He did so at one time.

6) Even if miraculous events ceased, spiritual gifts still benefit the body of Christ today.

7) The term "charisma" doesn't appear in the text; it might refer to the Spirit Himself or a broader use of "gifts."

8) Finally, Hebrews 2 starts by speaking of "the message declared by angels." The cessationist claims, "Now that the message has been delivered, we no longer need miraculous demonstrations." If the cessationist is going to be consistent, wouldn't this mean that there would also no longer be a need for angels?

In light of these points, the argument that Hebrews 2:3‚Äì4 supports cessationism appears unconvincing.

title: Responding to the "Cessationist" Documentary - Part #3 | Cessationist Movie Review
description:
Are the Charismatic gifts real? Speaking in tongues, prophesying, healing, and raising the dead ‚Äì do these phenomena exist? Charismatic and Pentecostal Christians firmly believe in their authenticity, viewing them as miraculous occurrences. The new documentary "Cessationist" boldly asserts that they have ceased. Under the direction of Les Lanphere,  the "Cessationist" film attempts to dismiss modern practices of spiritual gifts using speculation, church tradition, and human reasoning. Fortunately, the Word of God directly contradicts their confident assertions. In this 3rd installment of our response to the cessationist documentary, we will tackle 3 arguments from the Cessationist movie.

Argument #1: The Cessationist Hebrews 2:2-3 Argument
Tom Pennington, a respected figure from Countryside Bible Church, asserts that spiritual gifts ceased after the apostolic era. This assertion is based on Hebrews 2:2-3, where the writer seems to suggest that miracles were foundational but not the norm. Our response is a comprehensive 7-fold argument that peels back the layers of complexity within this passage. We will explore the multifaceted purposes of miracles beyond mere validation, examining the absence of exclusivity to the apostles, and meticulously analyzing the present tense of "bore witness." Discover how these intricacies challenge the cessationist stance, and how the text itself suggests the possibility of God continuing to bear witness through signs, wonders, and spiritual gifts.

Argument #2: "The Wicked Generation That Seeks A Sign" from Matthew 16
The documentary contends that Matthew 16:4 condemns seeking signs to validate faith. We will embark on a profound journey through the context of this verse, unveiling its true meaning. This passage was spoken by Jesus in response to the Pharisees and Sadducees who demanded a sign from heaven to test Him. Their motive was not genuine faith but a desire for on-demand miracles. We will demonstrate that Matthew 16:4 is not a rebuke against the use of spiritual gifts for evangelism, but rather a criticism of those who wanted God to prove Himself through signs. Explore how the apostles themselves sought signs and wonders as tools for God to reveal Himself to their enemies, illustrating the positive role of continuationism in opening doors for evangelism through miracles.

Argument #3: Misrepresentations Of Church History
Nathan Busenitz, the Executive Vice President of The Master's Seminary, makes the sweeping claim that the early church fathers unanimously believed in the cessation of miraculous gifts. This assertion is a distortion of church history. To set the record straight, we will present an extensive list of church fathers who not only held beliefs in the continuation of spiritual gifts but also actively practiced and endorsed supernatural manifestations, including healing and prophecy. From Justin Martyr to Thomas Aquinas, from Irenaeus to Teresa of √Åvila, discover the rich tapestry of Christian history that testifies to the ongoing presence of spiritual gifts throughout the ages.

Tune in to watch The Remnant Radio team respond to arguments put forth by cessationists such as Tom Pennington, Nathan Busenitz, and Scott Aniol. This live stream promises to be a thought-provoking experience for all who seek to understand the role of spiritual gifts in today's church and the true narrative of church history.

For our Cessationist study guide, subscribe to our newsletter at www.theremnantradio.com.

title: Dr. Jeffrey L. Seif Defends Tree Of Life Translation
description:
Join us on The Remnant Radio, as we dive into the world of Bible translations and the Tree of Life Version (TLV) with our special guest, Dr. Jeffrey Seif. Dr. Seif is a distinguished figure in the world of Messianic Judaism, renowned for his extensive contributions to biblical scholarship and his role as a key figure behind the TLV translation.

The Tree of Life Version (TLV) is a modern English translation of the Bible designed to reflect the Jewish roots and context of the Scriptures. While it aims to provide a clear and accurate representation of the original Hebrew and Greek texts, the TLV also preserves the Jewish cultural and linguistic elements found within the Bible. However, not everyone shares the same enthusiasm for this unique translation.

Mark Ward, a Bible scholar and TLV critic, has come on Remnant and expressed reservations about the TLV. He questions the extensive use of transliterated Hebrew terms in the translation and raises concerns about its intelligibility for a broader audience. Additionally, Mark Ward challenges the practice of replacing "Lord" in the New Testament with "ADONAI" and the use of Hebrew transliterations for certain terms. You can watch that episode here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TEiKbrXgp1o&t=12s

In this episode, Dr. Jeffrey Seif will defend and elaborate on the Tree of Life Version's merits, addressing Mark Ward's concerns and providing insights into the translation's purpose and significance. We'll explore the TLV's focus on maintaining the Jewish essence of the Bible and its role in connecting readers with the rich heritage of their faith.

Don't miss this episode as we delve into the world of Bible translations, examine the Tree of Life Version, and gain a deeper understanding of its place within the Messianic Jewish movement. 

Tree of Life Bible: https://tlvbiblesociety.org/collections/bibles

title: The Cluster Argument: Responding to Cessationism
description:
In this episode of The Remnant Radio,  we respond to Tom Pennington pastor of Countryside Bible Church, as he uses the Cluster argument to explain the cessation of spiritual gifts. Tom Pennington asserts that there are distinct periods in biblical history marked by a concentration of miracles, coinciding with significant stages in God's redemptive plan.

Cessationists claim that there are only three key periods of concentrated miracles in the Bible: the Moses and Joshua era, characterized by miracles during the Exodus and the conquest of Canaan; the Elijah and Elisha era, featuring supernatural acts confirming prophetic ministries in a spiritually declining Israel; and the Jesus and Apostles era, marked by miracles establishing the Christian church and confirming the authority of Jesus and the apostles as messengers of the New Covenant. Cessationists argue that during these periods, unique displays of divine power occurred, and therefore, miraculous gifts gradually diminished or ceased afterward. But is this argument rooted in biblical evidence, or is it a theological assertion imposed upon the text?

We contend that this argument is profoundly unbiblical and can be easily disproven with minimal effort. To start, Jeremiah 32:20-21 unequivocally states that God has performed signs and wonders from the time of Moses to the present day:

‚ÄúYou performed signs and wonders in Egypt and have continued them to this day, in Israel and among all mankind, and have gained the renown that is still yours. 21 You brought your people Israel out of Egypt with signs and wonders, by a mighty hand and an outstretched arm and with great terror.‚Äù

Additionally, the New Testament provides explicit time frames for when the gifts will cease, such as Acts 2, which mentions "in the last days," referring to the eschatological period leading up to the "day of the Lord" that we currently live in. Or consider 1 Corinthians 1:7, which explicitly states that the church in Corinth would abound in every gift until Christ appears. Moreover, 1 Corinthians 13:8-12 tells us that the gifts will cease when Christ returns. The Cluster argument stands as one of the weakest arguments in the cessationist arsenal, and in this episode of The Remnant Radio, we address it head-on.

title: Can Christians Be Demonized? Exploring Charismatic Teachings Of Demon Possession & Demon Oppression
description:
Join us as we delve into the widely held charismatic teachings that assert Christians cannot be demonized. We'll examine and challenge this belief by exploring two key quotes from prominent figures like Chuck Smith, as well as a comprehensive position paper from the Assemblies of God. With a balanced and respectful approach, we present counterarguments, drawing from biblical references and historical context to gently disagree and provide a compelling refutation of these charismatic notions.

But that's not all ‚Äì we take our investigation a step further by delving into the writings of church fathers who hold an opposing perspective. Through quotes and thoughtful commentary, we highlight the historical continuity of the belief that Christians can indeed be subject to demonic influence. By juxtaposing these historical perspectives with the modern charismatic stance, we aim to foster a deeper understanding of this complex theological topic.

Join us for an exploration that encourages critical thinking and a nuanced understanding of charismatic teachings regarding demonization. Whether you're a believer seeking to deepen your faith or simply interested in theological discussions, this video offers a comprehensive analysis that invites viewers to consider different viewpoints and engage in meaningful dialogue.

description:
Unveiling John Wimber's Beliefs About The NAR: Candid Insights from Carol Wimber

üé• Get ready for an eye-opening conversation as we delve into the beliefs and practices of John Wimber, a prominent figure in the evangelical world during the Jesus People movement. In this captivating interview, I sat down with none other than Carol Wimber herself, the wife of John Wimber, to uncover the truth about his stance on the New Apostolic Reformation (NAR) and his connection with the teachings of C. Peter Wagner.

üåü Carol, who was closer to John than anyone else, shares her unique insights and sets the record straight on whether John Wimber subscribed to the NAR ideology. Join us as we explore the depths of John's beliefs and practices, now that he has left us, with Carol as our guide.

üî• We tackled burning questions such as whether John and C. Peter Wagner saw eye to eye on the NAR, the concept of church organization under Apostles and Prophets, and the supernatural empowerment of church members through specific leadership structures.

ü§£ Amidst the enlightening conversation, Carol surprised us all with her candid sense of humor, recalling moments where John would humorously dismiss notions with phrases like "I am just a fat man trying to get to heaven." Her revelations about John's perspectives are both startling and heartwarming.

üïí While the full interview lasted over an hour, we've put together an engaging teaser that captures the essence of this thought-provoking discussion in just 60 seconds. Whether you're deeply interested in revival history, the charismatic movement, or are currently part of a Vineyard Church, this interview is a must-watch.

ü§ù Carol's words serve as a reminder that empowerment from God is accessible to all Christians and doesn't require complex structures or hoops to jump through. Her boldness in sharing these insights is bound to leave you both shocked and encouraged.

üîî Make sure to stay tuned for the full interview, where we uncover even more about John Wimber's beliefs and legacy. Share this teaser with fellow believers and seekers, and let's ignite a powerful conversation around faith, empowerment, and the charismatic movement.

üëç Don't miss out ‚Äì hit that subscribe button and turn on notifications so you'll be the first to catch the full interview when it drops! Get ready to be enlightened, entertained, and inspired by Carol Wimber's captivating revelations.

God blesses the beggars in spirit because theirs is Heavens‚Äô Empire.
God blesses the grievers because they will be consoled.
God blesses the meek because they will inherit the land.
God blesses the ones hungering and thirsting for the rightness because they will be satisfied. (Matthew 5:3-6)
Watch our interview with Scot and hear his insights.

title: What Is The Nicene Creed? Interview With Phillip Cary
description:
Nicene Creed | Nicene Creed explained | Nicene council | Nicene Creed history | What is the Nicene Crede? | Phillip Cary Nicene Creed

For centuries, the Nicene Creed has been central to the church‚Äôs confession. The Nicene Creed: An Introduction by Phillip Cary explores the Creed‚Äôs riches with simplicity and clarity. Cary explains the history of the Creed and walks through its meaning line by line. Far from being abstract or irrelevant, the words of the Creed carefully express what God has done in Christ and through the Spirit. The Nicene Creed gives us the gospel. It gives biblical Christians the words for what we already believe. And when we profess the Creed, we join the global church throughout history in declaring the name and work of the one God‚ÄïFather, Son, and Spirit. Gain a fresh appreciation for the ancient confession with Phillip Cary‚Äôs help. We'll interview Phillip and hear his insights.

title: The Historical Adam? Interview with Fuz Rana
description:
Christianity and biology | Christianity and science | Christianity and genetics | Christianity and science debate | Can Christianity and science coexist? | genetics Adam and Eve | Bible genetics | The Bible and genetic science | Christianity and evolution | Adam and Eve genetics | DNA Bible | DNA religion | DNA God

Who was Adam? Was he the result of still ongoing natural processes or a unique creation? In the original publication of Who Was Adam? (2005), biochemist Fazale Rana and astronomer Hugh Ross discussed cutting-edge research in junk DNA, the human fossil record, human and chimp genetic similarities, and more. They proposed a new scientific testable model for human origins. This robust 10-year update provides rigorous testing of the evolution and creation scenarios. New discoveries in genetics and paleoanthropology, especially, provide helpful evidence. How has RTB's biblically aligned model for human origins fared? Can human evolution be declared a fact? Or does a creation model make more scientific sense? We‚Äôll interview Fuz Rana and discuss his latest book on the show. Join us here live!

title: Reviewing The Tree Of Life Bible: Interview With Mark Ward @wardonwords
description:
The TLV or Tree of Life Version, is a Bible translation produced by the Messianic Jewish community. The TLV aims to restore Jewish names, themes, and cultures into an English Bible. Most Western Bible translations transliterate Hebrew words and themes into English in a way that would make sense to Western readers. However, many in the messianic movement believe these transliterations actually remove our historic connection to the Jewish people.

Today, scholar Mark Ward (remember him from our episode on the KJV only controversy?) joins us to discuss translation and transliteration as it pertains to most modern translations, including (and especially) the TLV. You won‚Äôt want to miss!

In response, you can watch Dr. Jeffrey Seif's defense of the TLV Bible here: https://youtube.com/live/9Q4UGF7_O5A

title: Were There Only 3 Periods Of Miracles? Debunking the Cessationist Cluster Argument!
description:
John MacArthur and other cessationist claim that God only did miracles in three clustered periods of redemptive history:  the life of Moses & Joshua, the life of Elijah and Elisha, and the life of Jesus and the Apostles. Cessationists argue that the gifts have ceased today in the same way that they ceased in between these clustered periods. Could this be true? Did the supernatural and miraculous signs of God end between these various periods? We think not! All this and more will be covered in this episode of Remnant Radio! See you all today at 4PM CST!

title: Are The Sign Gifts For Today? Responding to Ligonier Cessationist Arguments
description:
Cessationism is the theological belief that some supernatural gifts of the Spirit have ceased to operate in the Church. Cessationists (those who hold the doctrine of cessationism) often categorize tongues, healing, and other revelatory gifts as "sign gifts". These "sign gifts", as they are often called by cessationists, are believed to have ceased at the end of the Apostolic age, the closing of the cannon, or progressively ceased during the life of the apostles.  So, Are Sign Gifts For Today? In this episode, we will be listening and responding to cessationist arguments articulated by the respected scholarship over at Ligonier ministries. Here at The Remnant Radio, we think that all spiritual gifts, even the sign gifts are for today. Though we respect Steven Lawson, Stephen Nichols, and Burk Parsons, we strongly disagree with them over spiritual gifts and do not believe that their arguments hold water when compared to the continuationist arguments of Dr. Criag Keener, Dr. Sam Storms, D.A. Carson and others.

title: Interview With Jackie Pullinger - Christian Missionary, Author
description:
The Remnant Radio was honored to interview Christian missionary Jackie Pullinger on the show! Jackie Pullinger has dedicated her life to serving God and helping the poor and marginalized in Hong Kong. She is the founder of the St Stephen's Society, a charity that provides rehabilitation homes for recovering drug addicts, prostitutes, and gang members. She is also the author of several books, including Chasing the Dragon, which tells the story of her early years of ministry in the notorious Kowloon Walled City. She has received many honors and awards for her work, such as the MBE and an honorary degree from the University of Hong Kong. 

#remnantradio #spiritualgifts #christianmissionaries #christianmissions #christianmissionary #hongkong #godspeaks #charismatic #powerevangelism #giftsofthespirit

title: Who is the Antichrist? Interview with Kim Riddlebarger
description:
In this video, we interview Kim Riddlebarger about the identity of the Antichrist. What is the Antichrist? What does the Bible say about the Antichrist? The historic Christian faith holds to a conception of an "Anti-Christ" figure derived from the Christian scriptures, particularly The Book of Daniel, Thessalonians, and Revelation. This Antichrist is foretold as one who will ‚Äúspeak great words against the most-High and wear out the saints of the most-High, and think to change times and laws‚Äù (Daniel 7:25). He will also "He will oppose and will exalt himself over everything that is called God or is worshiped, so that he sets himself up in God‚Äôs temple, proclaiming himself to be God." (2 Thessalonians 2:4). 

But are these figures in Daniel and 2 Thessalonians future apocalyptic figures? Or was Daniel referring to a contemporary Hellenistic ruler of Palestine, Antiochus IV Epiphanes, who attempted to root out and destroy Judaism? Was Paul's "man of lawlessness" referring to Emperor Nero? The reformers were convinced the Antichrist was the Papecy or more specifically the Pope, while some modern scholars believe that all these historic men are an archetypal type of the future baddy we all know as THE ANTICHRIST! 

Is the Antichrist revealed in End Times Eschatology?

All this and more as we discuss "Who is the Antichrist" in this episode of The Remnant Radio!

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: Spiritual Warfare in The Book of Job: Interview With Dr. Bob Chisholm
description:
Join us for a fascinating exploration of spiritual warfare through the lens of the Book of Job with Dr. Bob Chisholm, Senior Professor at Dallas Theological Seminary. After 42 years of scholarly work, Dr. Chisholm brings fresh insights into how Job‚Äôs suffering fits within a larger cosmic conflict.

We‚Äôll explore the supernatural dimensions of Job‚Äôs story, including: ‚Ä¢ The Divine Council and Satan‚Äôs role ‚Ä¢ The true identity of Leviathan, Behemoth, and other creatures ‚Ä¢ How Job‚Äôs suffering relates to spiritual warfare ‚Ä¢ The relationship between righteousness and spiritual attack ‚Ä¢ Practical implications for believers facing trials today

Drawing from ancient Near Eastern context and careful biblical analysis, Dr. Chisholm helps us understand that sometimes believers suffer not because of sin, but because of righteousness. This groundbreaking perspective challenges common assumptions about suffering while offering hope to those experiencing trials.

Join us as we discover how Job‚Äôs ancient story provides crucial insights into spiritual warfare and divine purposes in suffering.

title: Pastors Discuss Homosexuality: Interview With Becket Cook
description:
We welcomed Becket Cook (@BecketCook) to the show to share his powerful testimony! When Becket Cook moved from Dallas to Los Angeles after college, he discovered a socially progressive, liberal town that embraced not only his creative side but also his homosexuality. He devoted his time to growing his career as a successful set designer and to finding "the one" man who would fill his heart. As a gay man in the entertainment industry, Cook centered his life around celebrity-filled Hollywood parties and traveled to society hot-spots around the world--until a chance encounter with a pastor at an LA coffee shop one morning changed everything.

In A Change of Affection, Becket Cook shares his testimony as someone who was transformed by the power of the gospel. Cook's dramatic conversion to Christianity and subsequent seminary training inform his views on homosexuality--personally, biblically, theologically, and culturally--and in his new book he educates Christians on how to better understand this complex and controversial issue while revealing how to lovingly engage with those who disagree. A Change of Affection is a timely and indispensable resource for anyone who desires to understand more fully one of the most common and difficult stumbling blocks to faithfully following Christ today.

title: The Unity Of Christ!
description:
Was Jesus fully God, fully man, or something else? What is the unity of Christ? Join us for a fascinating deep dive into one of Christianity‚Äôs most crucial debates!

In this episode of The Remnant Radio, we‚Äôre joined by Hunter Heinzmann, a brilliant theological scholar from Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, to unpack the ancient controversy that shaped how we understand Jesus today. We‚Äôll explore:

‚Ä¢ The explosive 5th-century showdown between Cyril and Nestorius ‚Ä¢ Why calling Mary the ‚ÄúMother of God‚Äù sparked a theological firestorm ‚Ä¢ How ancient church debates still matter for modern Christians ‚Ä¢ What it means that Jesus was both fully God and fully human ‚Ä¢ Why getting this wrong can wreck your understanding of salvation

Whether you‚Äôre a theology buff or just curious about the foundations of Christian faith, this episode offers clear explanations of complex ideas that matter for every believer. Don‚Äôt miss this enlightening conversation about who Jesus really is!

Join Josh Lewis, Michael Roundtree, and special guest Hunter Heinzmann as we tackle one of Christianity‚Äôs most important questions: Who exactly is Jesus Christ?

title: What does "Only Begotten Son Of God" really mean? Interview with Dr. Charles Lee Irons
description:
Is Jesus the "One and only son of God?" or Is Jesus the "Only begotten son of God?" Since the beginning of the 20th century, there has been great debate over the translation of this Greek word. title: Does God Cry? Discussions On Impassibility with Amos Winarto
description:
Does God Cry: Discussions On Impassibility with Amos Winarto 

Does God have emotions? Without much thought, many of us instinctually say ‚ÄúYES!‚Äù Maybe you think back to the passages of scripture where God‚Äôs anger is kindled. Or where men and women of the bible work to please God. Or maybe even scriptures on God‚Äôs compassion for the widows and orphans. Well, philosophers describe God‚Äôs emotions very differently than we do. They suggest, if we can do something to make God happy, make God angry, or make God cry, then we control the uncontrollable, and we can change the unchangeable? The theological position that states that God‚Äôs emotions are unchangeable is called impassability. Listen as Dr. Amos Winarto discusses this philosophical/theological doctrine regarding the emotions of God.

title: Weekly Communion - A Tradition or Command? Interview with Kenneth Wieting
description:
What is Communion? What is Eucharist? Weekly Communion was the normative practice of the church for nearly three centuries. However, by the 4th-century reports began to emerge of congregants being unwilling or unable to take the Lord's Table. The balance of seeing God with both transcendence and immanence was lost and the church could not imagine fellowshipping with God in communion. Christians pictured God as too lofty - too different - too unapproachable. Eventually, the Lord's Table was reserved only for the priest, the "holiest" of which could partake monthly.  Nearly a millennium later the Protestant reformation brings communion back to center stage. This "communion revival" re-situated the Church around the table in faith and fellowship with Christ Jesus. In recent centuries the church has once again fallen off kilter with the commands of the Holy Eucharist. Many argue that the table is merely a symbol that should not be institutionalized, and others fear religious repetition will cause communion to lose its much-needed reverence. So what should we do concerning holy communion? Should believers practice the table monthly, weekly, or daily? Can Christians take communion on their own without a Church? Are all the rules about communion man-made traditions?

title: Imprecatory Psalms: Interview With Trevor Laurence
description:
"Lord, help me love my neighbor, also would you knock out the teeth of my enemy and break their jaws? (Psalm 3:7) Amen!"

Today we are looking at passages you won't find illustrated in the Precious Moments Bible! Buckle up! We are talking about Imprecatory Psalms! Christians are told to love their enemies and pray for those who persecute them, but should we also pray for justice and judgment to befall our enemies? Trevor Laurence, Joshua Lewis, and Michael Rowntree discuss the imprecatory psalms and their implications in the Christian Life, their biblical-theological framework, and how they can and should be incorporated in our liturgy and worship.

title: God Is doing Something At The Asbury Revival #shorts
description:
God Is Doing Something At The Asbury Revival #shorts 

Remnant's Thoughts On The Asbury Revival!

Hughes Auditorium has been hosting a chapel service since Wednesday, February 8th. Since then services have had public confessions, repentance, worship (of all kinds), proclamation (preaching and testimonies), prayer, and public scripture readings. These services are low-hype somber and worshipful. People come to kneel at the altar railing as the Holy Spirit prompts them without hyped-up altar calls. There are reports of healings and prophetic utterances. Hughes Auditorium has reached capacity multiple times over the past week, and Estes Chapel across the street at Asbury Theological Seminary has been opened for overflow. Yet there are still lines that stretch throughout the campus with hundreds maybe thousands of people waiting on a touch from God.

I was so excited to see what God was doing that I flew out on Monday to experience the revival firsthand! Yesterday, we filmed updates on the revival and shared our thoughts about the mighty work that God is doing at Asbury Seminary. There are lots of opinions circling around the rival right now. We have critiques calling it "emotionalism" and many Charismatics saying it is "the fulfillment of a Bob Jones Prophecy". We address all that and more in this episode.

title: If God had Poured Out The Asbury Revival On Sodom and Gomorrah They Would Have Repented #shorts
description:
If God had Poured Out The Asbury Revival On Sodom and Gomorrah They Would Have Repented #shorts 

Remnant's Thoughts On The Asbury Revival!

Hughes Auditorium has been hosting a chapel service since Wednesday, February 8th. Since then services have had public confessions, repentance, worship (of all kinds), proclamation (preaching and testimonies), prayer, and public scripture readings. These services are low-hype somber and worshipful. People come to kneel at the altar railing as the Holy Spirit prompts them without hyped-up altar calls. There are reports of healings and prophetic utterances. Hughes Auditorium has reached capacity multiple times over the past week, and Estes Chapel across the street at Asbury Theological Seminary has been opened for overflow. Yet there are still lines that stretch throughout the campus with hundreds maybe thousands of people waiting on a touch from God.

I was so excited to see what God was doing that I flew out on Monday to experience the revival firsthand! Yesterday, we filmed updates on the revival and shared our thoughts about the mighty work that God is doing at Asbury Seminary. There are lots of opinions circling around the rival right now. We have critiques calling it "emotionalism" and many Charismatics saying it is "the fulfillment of a Bob Jones Prophecy". We address all that and more in this episode.

title: It Is Impossible For Asbury To Be A Work Of The Flesh #shorts
description:
It Is Impossible For Asbury To Be A Work Of The Flesh #shorts  
Remnant's Thoughts On The Asbury Revival!

Hughes Auditorium has been hosting a chapel service since Wednesday, February 8th. Since then services have had public confessions, repentance, worship (of all kinds), proclamation (preaching and testimonies), prayer, and public scripture readings. These services are low-hype somber and worshipful. People come to kneel at the altar railing as the Holy Spirit prompts them without hyped-up altar calls. There are reports of healings and prophetic utterances. Hughes Auditorium has reached capacity multiple times over the past week, and Estes Chapel across the street at Asbury Theological Seminary has been opened for overflow. Yet there are still lines that stretch throughout the campus with hundreds maybe thousands of people waiting on a touch from God.

I was so excited to see what God was doing that I flew out on Monday to experience the revival firsthand! Yesterday, we filmed updates on the revival and shared our thoughts about the mighty work that God is doing at Asbury Seminary. There are lots of opinions circling around the rival right now. We have critiques calling it "emotionalism" and many Charismatics saying it is "the fulfillment of a Bob Jones Prophecy". We address all that and more in this episode.

title: The Secret Shantung Revival Of 1927
description:
A major revival occurred in 1927-1935 called at that time the Shantung Revival (now often referred to as the Shandong Revival). While it involved Presbyterians, Pentecostals, and Baptists, I have focused on the Baptist story.  Baptist missionaries during the revival experienced or observed divine healings, speaking in tongues, visions etc... and other practices that were associated with Pentecostalism.  Baptists back in the USA became concerned and questioned the missionaries.  The story is a case of "charismatic Baptists" much earlier than the charismatic stories of the 1960s and following.  Baptists in recent decades like to cite the revival as a great evangelistic success but have difficulty admitting the charismatic practices (and often try to mute their existence)

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: By His Stripes We Are Healed..But Not Physically: Responding To Allan Parr's Teaching On Isaiah 53:5
description:
I consider Allan Parr one of the best examples of a Christian YouTuber out there. The guy cranks out solid content every week with biblically sound teachings. He carefully and kindly identifies false teachings, while simultaneously showing us the historic Christian Faith seen in the scriptures. Suffice to say, he has been an inspiration to all of us here at Remnant Radio. 

"As always all of us in the faith find areas of disagreement in non-essential doctrines and we want to lovingly challenge one another presenting the best arguments with kindness and generosity. While rare we have found one contention with Alan Parr's interpretation of Isaiah 53. On Apr 5, 2019, Allan published a video Titled "Does God Promise us Divine Healing?". In this video, Allan explains that the frequently quoted Isaiah 53:5 text is not about physical healing. This video pulled in over 119,000 Views, and like all of Allan's content, it was done with professionalism, Christian Charity, and careful Exegesis. That being said, we think he's wrong ;).

In this video, we will be responding to Allan Parr's claims that "Isaiah 53:5 is not about healing"

title: Progressive Covenantalism Explained: Interview with Steve Wellum
description:
In this enlightening episode of Remnant Radio, Dr. Stephen Wellum from Southern Baptist Theological Seminary joins Josh Lewis and Michael Roundtree to explore the complex relationship between the Old and New Testaments through the lens of Progressive Covenantalism. Dr. Wellum breaks down the differences between traditional Dispensationalism, Covenant Theology, and Progressive Covenantalism, explaining how biblical covenants serve as the backbone for understanding Scripture‚Äôs unity. The discussion delves into how each covenant from Adam to Christ progressively reveals God‚Äôs redemptive plan, challenging oversimplified interpretations of biblical law and offering a fresh perspective on how Christians should understand their relationship to Old Testament commands. Whether you‚Äôre a theology student or simply interested in better understanding how the Bible fits together, this episode provides valuable insights into how all of Scripture points to and finds its fulfillment in Christ.

Key topics include:

The progression of biblical covenants
Differences between Old and New Covenants
How to interpret Old Testament law today
The relationship between Israel and the Church
Christ as the fulfillment of all covenants

title: Should We Unhitch Sexual Morality From the Bible? Investigating Andy Stanley's LGBT Views
description:
Should We Unhitch Sexual Morality From the Bible? Investigating Andy Stanley's LGBT Views

40,000 congregants and perhaps millions of people around the world look to Andy Stanley for spiritual guidance, but should they? Years ago Andy Stanley was thrust into controversy when he encouraged his congregation to "unhitch from the Old Testament." 

Most recently, the controversy has been stirred by viral social media posts that have threatened to expose Andy Stanley as a heretic. "Why?" you may ask. Well, the claim is that Andy Stanley has become an LGBTQI+-affirming pastor. It appears Andy Stanley is now encouraging his church to "unhitch" morality from the Bible altogether. Join us as Josh, Michael, and Michael investigate the claims about Andy Stanley and discuss what Christians should do when pastors become LGBT-affirming. 

#remnantradio #theology #theologypodcast #theologydiscussion #biblepodcast #christianpodcast

title: Debunking The Pre-Trib Rapture With Joel Richardson
description:
We welcomed Joe Richardson to the show to hear his viewpoints on the pretribulation vs post tribulation debate and the Rapture. Joel Richardson is a Christian author and teacher who has written several books on biblical prophecy and the end times. He is also a critic of the pre-tribulation rapture doctrine, which is the belief that the church will be taken to heaven before the seven-year period of tribulation that precedes the second coming of Christ. He argues that this doctrine is not supported by the scriptures, the early church fathers, or the historical context of the book of Revelation. He believes that the church will go through the tribulation and be raptured at the end of it, when Christ returns in glory.

Join us as we wade into the pre trib vs post trib debate.

#remnantradio #rapture #bookofrevelation #revelation #eschatology #endtimes

title: Early Church's Prophetic Ministry In North Africa: A Look At Early Montanism
description:
Early Church's Prophetic Ministry In North Africa: A Look At Early Montanism

There is this crazy thought that the charismatic movement began at the Azuza street revival In 1906. However, the Charismatics have been around for a hot minute, and there has been good, bad, and ugly surrounding the movement from day 1!  It would be a huge disservice to the charismatic space to try and reinvent the wheel when it comes to Prophetquette (prophetic etiquette) since we have had many conversations about this throughout church history. 

So in this episode, we are diving Into the early Church's Prophetic ministry. We will be closely examining the church history surrounding those "ancient Charismatics" in north Africa! Should be an exciting program!

With the new year comes new prophetic words, and with new prophetic words comes the testing of prophetic words. Four days ago Charisma News published a YouTube video titled "Compilation of 2023 PROPHETIC WORDS". At the time of this post, their YouTube video has 89,000 views. title: Mother Mary's Miracles, Messages, and Appearances: Protestants Discuss Mariology
description:
Did you know there are these wild stories of Mother Mary appearing to people all over the world? Yeah! Apparently, for a couple HUNDRED YEARS, people have been claiming to see Mary the mother of Jesus. In these supposed encounters, Mary shows up, sometimes to GROUPS of people, delivers a message, sometimes heals people, and then vanishes. What do we think of these appearances? Find out in this episode.

title: The Forgotten Ascension: Interview With Gordon T. Smith
description:
Why is the Ascension of Jesus so important? Discover the forgotten doctrine that unlocks the power of the gospel for your everyday life!

Join Michael Rowntree as he interviews Dr. Gordon Smith about the often-overlooked doctrine of the Ascension of Jesus. Dr. Smith explains why the Ascension is essential for understanding the gospel, arguing that it fulfills the incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection. Learn how the ascended Lord ministers to us today and how you can experience his kingdom power in your daily work and worship.

title: Does God Cause Sickness: A Look At Corporate Guilt
description:
Does God cause sickness? Last week we looked at how God used sickness in both OT and NT. This week we are taking a deeper dive into corporate guilt. It appears that God pours out plagues, sicknesses, and diseases on those who are in rebellion against him. Often times we even see God afflicting the seemingly "innocent" with sickness, disease, and death due to the sins of those in proximity to them. How should Christians interpret these passages? All this and more in this episode of The Remnant Radio.

title: Christians Discuss Extraterrestrials! Interview With Jeff Zweerink
description:
Is there Alien life out there? It is a question that is not going away any time soon. With the increasing regularity of UAP sightings by the US military, the explosion of science fiction movies, and the popularity of new-age mythology, the alien conversation is now unavoidable. Whether it's a casual conversation about entertainment or a serious conversation about religious experiences, these conversations about aliens pose a unique moment in Christian history that believers should not shrink back from. We should have apologetics to address many people's concerns and questions regarding the potentiality of extraterrestrial life. Today we hope to do just that with Dr. Jeff Zweerink, senior research scholar with Reasons to Believe.

title: Are There Spiritual Gifts That Are Not Listed In Scripture?
description:
Are There Spiritual Gifts That Are Not Listed In Scripture?

There are three lists of spiritual gifts most people point to when studying the Gifts of The Spirit. List one is found in Romans 12, List two can be found in 1 Corinthians 12, and list three can be found in Ephesians 4. But why are they different lists? Why does Paul leave out healing, tongues, and administration in Ephesians 4? or why isn't there a mention of evangelism in 1 Corinthians 12? It appears that each of these lists was not meant to be exhaustive. If that is true, then might there be other Spirit-empowered gifts that Christ has given his church, gifts unmentioned in scripture? All this and more today at 4PM CST!

title: Aimee Semple McPherson & The Complexities of Christian Celebrities
description:
Aimee Semple McPherson & The Complexities of Christian Celebrities

Starting off the week by talking about the life and teachings of Aimee Semple McPherson. Aimee was a Canadian Pentecostal evangelist and media celebrity in the 1920s and 1930s, famous for founding the Foursquare Church. McPherson pioneered the use of broadcast mass media, she used radio, popular entertainment techniques, and stage theatrics, in her weekly sermons that popularized her name in an unprecedented way. 
Our good buddy Anthony Scoma is joining us for the discussion. Anthony has been on the show twice before once covering the History of the Assemblies of God and the history of race in the AG.

Anthony is a 4th generation member of the Assemblies of God on both sides of his family. He graduated from UT with a degree in history, he received a Master of Divinity from SAGU, then went to Austin Presbyterian Theological Seminary for a master's in historical Theology. In Anthony‚Äôs words, he has been tried by Presbyterians, Pentecostals, and Pagans ü§£ü§£ü§£. 

As you can imagine, someone with such a diverse education is absolutely fascinating to talk to. Tune in tomorrow at 4PM CST to catch this program.

description:
In this episode, we discuss honor culture and the concept of "Don't touch the Lord's anointed."

"Don't touch the Lord's Anointed" . . . "you should have spoken to them privately" . . .  and maybe my favorite "Judge not lest YEEEE be Judged" are all comments that we see too frequently on our YouTube channel. But is there really a biblical prohibition to confronting teaching we disagree with? Are there hoops we need to jump through before we disagree? Or maybe disagreement itself is quarrelsome and divisive. We will discuss all this and more today at 4PM CST!

title: Witchcraft, Wicca, and Neo-Paganism: Spooky Evangelism Episode 3
description:
In this series, we examine magical practices, Satanism, Wicca, witchcraft and neopaganism to learn how we can connect the Gospel to people who participate in the occult. Our culture is starving for spiritual experiences while championing moral relativism. Neopaganism checks all the boxes for this cultural moment. Wicca, witchcraft, and neopaganism are growing at rapid rates in the west, and it feels like the church is two steps behind the culture. 

In this episode, we'll have neopaganism explained, looking at neopagan rituals and neopaganism practices. If you want to learn how to connect the Gospel to those practicing Wicca, witchcraft, or other forms of neopaganism, you need to check out this episode of The Remnant Radio.

title: Atonement Theories
description:
In this episode of Remnant Radio about atonement theories, Josh Lewis and Michael Rowntree explore five major theories of atonement in Christian theology. They discuss the moral influence theory, recapitulation, ransom theory, Christus Victor, and penal substitutionary atonement, explaining how these different models help us understand what was accomplished through Christ‚Äôs death on the cross. Rather than pitting these theories against each other, we demonstrate how each model captures different aspects of Christ‚Äôs saving work, while addressing common misconceptions and contemporary debates surrounding atonement theology.

title: Responding To Culture Of Honor
description:
Today we are taking a look at the popular charismatic book "Culture of Honor" By Danny Silk. In this book, Danny gives the "secret sauce" to Bethel's success. He claims that honoring individuals for who God has called them to be has been the foundation for the success of the movement. 
However, after reading "culture of honor" we found It to be more of a charismatic ecclesiological playbook. A playbook that frankly dishonors the gifts of the Spirit that God has established In his church. 

Honestly, a big part of me does not want to respond to this book. I think Danny Silk is trying to respond to an unhealthy imbalance of spiritual gifts, and he is trying to solve a real problem in the body of Christ. Unfortunately, he is overcorrecting and erroring in the opposite direction. I fear that videos like this make us look unnecessarily combative. Nevertheless, I have been told by multiple Charismatic leaders that this book is the epicenter of the toxic Charismatic culture we are seeing everywhere. So, in this video, we will be spending most of our time responding to the claims Danny made in Chapter 2. Hopefully, we can engage with Danny's teachings without mincing words or pulling punches while still Honoring the man who has made such positive Impacts In the body of Christ. 

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: History of Magic In The Bible: Spooky Evangelism Episode 1
description:
In this series, we examine magical practices, Satanism, Wicca, witchcraft and neopaganism to learn how we can connect the Gospel to people who participate in the occult. "Why are Christians studying the History of Magic?" you may be asking yourself. Well, Judaism is the historic epicenter of monotheism, which means all the other ancient near eastern cultures mentioned in the Old Testament lived in a mystical, polytheistic society, hell-bent on controlling their own destinies through sorcery. Turns out, if you understand the worldview of those in the "dark arts," you actually have a decent grasp of the ancient near eastern worldview.

title: Identifying Toxic Church Cultures: Interview With Scot McKnight
description:
Tragically, in recent years, Christians have gotten used to revelations of abuses of many kinds in our most respected churches‚Äïfrom Willow Creek to Harvest, from Southern Baptist pastors to Sovereign Grace churches.

One of the best books I have read this year is "A Church Called Tov" by Scot McKnight, which addresses this very issue. The sad truth is that churches of all shapes and sizes are susceptible to abuses of power, sexual abuse, and spiritual abuse. Abuses occur most frequently when Christians neglect to create a culture that resists abuse and promotes healing, safety, and spiritual growth.

How do we keep these devastating events from repeating themselves? We need a map to get us from where we are today to where we ought to be as the body of Christ. Today Scott will be giving us steps to identify toxic cultures, but also how to build healthy church culture where the body of Christ can flourish. 

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: The Future Of The Charismatic Movement!
description:
The Charismatic movement in the west has been marked by three distinct moves of God. Wave  #1 was the Pentecostal movement. Pentecostalism was the first wave of the Spirit which broke over the church In 1906 at Azusa. Wave #2 was the charismatic movement often dated to 1959 where mainline churches encountered, what they called, "the baptism of the Spirit". From this wave emerged Charismatic Anglicans, Charismatic Lutherans, Charismatic Presbyterians, Charismatic Roman Catholics, Charismatic Methodists, and more. Wave #3 was the Neo-Charismatic wave where the gifts of the Spirit began making their way into evangelical churches. These moves of God have marked the charismatic movement, but what's The Future Of The Charismatic Movement!? 

We believe that there is a 4th wave of renewal coming to the Charismatic Movement, but what could it look like, and what should we be expecting? All this and more in this episode of The Remnant Radio. 

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: Debunking The Pre-Trib Rapture! With Dr. Alan E. Kurschner
description:
In this episode of The Remnant Radio, we interview Dr. Alan Kurschner and discuss the  pretribulation versus post tribulation debate and the Rapture. 

Alan E. Kurschner (Ph.D., McMaster Divinity College) is a biblical scholar committed to proclaiming the good news of God‚Äôs salvation in this dark world and heralding the second coming of his Son, Jesus Christ. Dr. Kurschner is the author of the popular book Antichrist Before the Day of the Lord: What Every Christian Needs to Know about the Return of Christ. His primary area of research is the book of Revelation, which includes A Linguistic Approach to Revelation 19:11‚Äì20:6 and the Millennium Binding of Satan. He is the owner of Eschatos Ministries.

title: Our Thoughts On Fire Tunnels üî•
description:
Today we are tackling the popular practice of "Fire Tunnels". A fire tunnel is two lines of people facing one another (like a cheer tunnel that you would see in a football game) and as people walk down the tunnel those lined up on both sides lay hands and pray for the individuals walking through the tunnel. 

Why is this controversial? Well, there is a good bit of photage online of people shaking, convulsing, and even falling to the ground as they walk through this line for prayer. So is this practice biblical? Is it demonic? If it is permissible, is it even helpful? All this and more in this episode of Remnant Radio!

title: Creation Science 101: Interview with Astrophysicist Hugh Ross
description:
In this episode of Remnant Radio about creation science, Dr. Hugh Ross, astrophysicist and founder of Reasons to Believe, joins Joshua Lewis and Michael Rowntree to explore how science points to the existence of God. Dr. Ross discusses the fine-tuning of the universe, the anthropic principle, and the incredible precision required for life to exist on Earth. The conversation covers topics ranging from the age of the Earth and the creation of Adam and Eve to the Cambrian explosion and the scientific evidence for intelligent design. Dr. Ross provides compelling evidence for how modern scientific discoveries continue to affirm biblical truth and strengthen the case for a divine Creator.

title: 7 Levels of Prophecy: Interview with R. T. Kendall
description:
What do you think when you hear "Word & Spirit"? I think of the reformed pastor R.T. Kendall. R.T. was raised Nazarene, then went charismatic reformed, and trained under the late Martin Loyd Jones! Now Dr. Kendall is a scholar of scholars, but he also used to hang In some pretty ghosty spaces. After reading his new book "Prophetic Integrity" I learned that he and Paul Cain used to do conferences together! What a wild duo Paul Cain and R.T. Kendall. 

Anyway, today we are hanging out with Mr. Word and Spirit himself, and we are talking about the 7 kinds of prophecy that R.T. lays out in his most recent book "prophetic integrity". Should be a great episode, See you all at 4PM CST!

title: Responding Cessationist - Kickstarter Trailer PART 2
description:
Responding Cessationist - Kickstarter Trailer PART 2

Recently a group of filmmakers at "logic on fire" released a Kickstarter campaign for a documentary/film called "cessationist". The Kickstarter page claims that this film will "lovingly and carefully" disprove the charismatic doctrines. And that sounded really nice until I watched the trailer, where cessationists say things like "Cessationism has fallen out of favor because commitment to the authority of scripture has fallen out of favor". The trailer is literally two and a half minutes of strawman arguments that may apply to the wildly extreme hyper charismatic fringes, but certainly do not apply to the growing movement of careful continuationist. So today at 4PM CST we will engage with more Cessationist one-liners, but this time we will be addressing the one-liners from the Kickstarter commercial.

title: Was Jesus Really Forsaken?
description:
Was Christ truly forsaken on the cross? It‚Äôs a question that strikes at the heart of Christian theology. Join Joshua Lewis and Michael Rowntree as they wrestle with this complex issue, exploring the Trinity, the hypostatic union, and the weight of Jesus‚Äôs cry, ‚ÄúMy God, my God, why have you forsaken me?‚Äù

This episode delves into the profound theological implications of Christ‚Äôs suffering, carefully examining the tension between Jesus‚Äôs divine nature and his human experience of abandonment. Michael and Joshua navigate the complexities of Psalm 22, typology, and the doctrine of penal substitutionary atonement, considering both sides of this difficult question.

Listeners will gain a deeper understanding of the Trinity, the nature of Christ‚Äôs sacrifice, and the power of God‚Äôs love, learning to articulate a nuanced and biblically sound perspective on the events of the crucifixion. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned theologian or simply curious about the depths of Christian doctrine, this episode will challenge you to consider the true weight of Christ‚Äôs sacrifice.

Michaels Psalm 22 Sermon

title: God's Plan for Israel - Dispensationalism Explained: Interview With Dr. Darrell Bock
description:
God's Plan for Israel - Dispensationalism Explained: Interview With Dr. Darrell Bock

What the heck is dispensationalism? Dispensationalism, if you didn‚Äôt already know, is a theological system of interpretation that is wildly popular in evangelical churches. The doctrine of Christ‚Äôs eminent return, Israel being a prophetic time clock, and even Christian books and films such as Left Behind, are all inspired by dispensational theology.

Since dispensationalism is hermeneutic, it impacts nearly every area of our Christian theology. It particularly affects the way that we view the nation of Israel, the land of Israel, and the nation of Israel's role in the end times.

Dispensationalism is such a broad topic! Fortunately for us, we have an expert coming on today to discuss the tenets of dispensationalism. Dr. Darrell Boch is the Executive Director of Cultural Engagement and Senior Research Professor of New Testament Studies at Dallas Theological Seminary, He is the author of over 40 books, and was one of the former presidents of the Evangelical Theological Society. We are excited to have Dr. Bock back on the show today, and we can't wait to dive Into some dispensational eschatology. 

See you all at 4PM CST!
https://youtu.be/gXRupVVw6TU

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: Are Ephesians 4 Gifts Offices of the Church, Personalities types, or grace gifts?
description:
Early on in my charismatic history, I understood that the Ephesians 4 gifts were offices that God instituted to govern the local church.  Later on In the journey, I stumbled upon Alan Hirsh‚Äôs work, suggesting that the Ephesians 4 giftsÔøº were more like personality typesÔøº that motivated us and painted our interpretation processes. After that my reformed charismatic buddies tried to convince me that the Ephesians 4 gifts were graces given by God detached from our personalities or our participation within the local communities. ü§îü§îü§îÔøºÔøº

In this episode, we are presenting these three views and examining their biblical validity of them.

title: Cultural Apologetics: Interview With Dustin Messer
description:
Have you heard about "cultural apologetics"? In the past, I have heard cultural apologetics being described as "making the gospel relevant and palatable to culture" and that sounds too much like compromising easy believeism. Other times I hear that we need to "Christianize the worldview of the nations" and that sounded too much like a theonomy. 

My new Anglican buddy Dustin Messer comes on the show today to discuss the necessity to reach a post-Christian culture with the Gospel. Dustin gives us a palatable approach to cultural apologetics that is both biblical and achievable. It was a fascinating discussion, I hope you all enjoy.

title: Our Thoughts On The Supreme Court Ruling: Theological Arguments For Life and the Imago Dei
description:
Our Thoughts On The Supreme Court Ruling: Theological Arguments For Life and the Imago Dei

This week we have seen a dramatic change in the national laws of the land. With the supreme courts overturn of Roe vs Wade the uncomfortable yet necessary conversation of abortion will be once again thrown back into the public square for discussion and debate. As a hot-button ethical and political issue, friends, families, and coworkers will be introducing this conversation with much passion and fiery fervor. Additionally, entire states will be deciding if they will condone, limit, or abolish abortions altogether.

This is not the time to kick back and relax. We need to be sharpened by the strongest biblical, theological, and philosophical arguments in order to make the case for the life of the unborn. In this episode, we will be making the biblical case for the life of the unborn while equipping you with arguments and responses for those who endorse and defend abortion.

description:

However, this kind of CEO leadership has found its way into the church and has caused moral failures, abusive leaders, and disorganized communities. title: God's Spirit in Worship (Full Video)
description:
God's Spirit in Worship

Evangelicalism in the west has made a big deal about encountering God in our praise and worship in the past century. The Charismatics in particular have popularized this position to the point where prayer and worship are almost exclusively the way that we encounter God's Spirit in our churches. But is this Biblical? Does the Bible connect the habitation of the Spirit with the praise and worship of God by his people? 

In this video, we will be looking at the Old Testament and the New Testament in search of biblical passages that support worship music as a means of God's grace to his people. In particular, we will be looking for the manifestation of the Spirit as they are connected to worship music.

I am often told that Bethel Church in Redding California does not preach the TRUE Gospel. But is that true? If you watch Remnant you will know that we are not Bethel fan boys. title: Is There A Wrong Way To Read The Bible: With Mark Ward
description:
Is There A Wrong Way To Read The Bible: With Mark Ward

Have you ever sat in a bible study, Sunday school, or maybe even a sermon when a well-intentioned believer teaches the bible in a way that completely dishonors the text of scripture itself? We have all seen it, and we have all done it! It's embarrassing to do, our hearts break for those who are doing it, and worst of all we are fearful that the error might actually negatively affect those who are hearing the teaching. But how can we avoid making errors like this in our biblical studies? Well in this episode of The Remnant Radio we want to help you avoid those ‚Äúexegetical fallacies‚Äù. And if that sounds complicated just know that‚Äôs a fancy way of saying ‚Äúhow to avoid mistakes when reading scripture‚Äù. Who better to help us tackle this idea than Mark Ward. Mark Ward holds a PhD in New Testament Interpretation from BJU Seminary, he is the academic editor at Lexam press, writes frequently on Bible study for Faithlife blogs and magazines, and is the host of the Bible Study Magazine Podcast. I am trying to say that he is overqualified! It is going to be an exciting and enlightening episode!

title: Is the Enneagram Demonic?
description:

title: Platonic Philosophy In Christian Theology: With Dr. Louis Markos
description:
In this episode of The Remnant Radio, we are talking about the Greek Philosophy Plato! Plato had incalculable impact on western thought, but how much impact should he have on the Christian faith? Many claim that platonic philosophy was responsible for cult groups like the gnostics, because of these accusations many more have chosen to write off many of the early church fathers altogether. Why? Well, It appears that they too were infected with this platonic philosophy. But was platonic philosophy inherently evil and anti-christian, or was platonic philosophy one of the necessary preconditions that prepared for the appearance of Christ? 

In this highly requested theology podcast, we will be interviewing Dr. Louis Markos who is quite the expert on all things Plato. Dr. Markos has published a book with IVP called "From Plato to Christ: How Platonic Thought Shaped the Christian Faith" which is quite insightful both for the negative and positive byproducts of platonic philosophy within the Christian faith.

title: Charismatic Legalism: Confusing Convictions With Commandments
description:
Charismatic Legalism: When We Confusing Convictions With Commandments

In this episode of The Remnant Radio Michael, Michael and Josh are covering the Charismatic convictions that exist within the charismatic movement. Is it wrong to watch Harry Potter or Pokemon? Are there hidden cultic images in the Toco Bell logo or the Monster Energy drink can? Can we, or should we give our money to organizations like Target, Disney, and Starbucks if they promote anti-Christian values? Can a Christian enjoy a beer? Some may think these convictions are silly, others may find the reasons for these convictions compelling, but what does the word of God say? Fortunately for us, there are both principles and commands in the Scriptures that can guide us through discerning if these convictions are personal or universal. 

We need to realize that every single culture reads Scripture with its own cultural mores. Charismatics are no more guilty of confusing their own code of ethics with the ethics of the Bible, than any other denomination or movement with Christianity. That being said, we are a charismatic theology podcast, and it's probably a good thing for us to want to talk this stuff out.

title: What Is Critical Race Theory? And Is Critical Race Theory Biblical?
description:
What is Critical Race Theory? Also popularly called CRT, Critical Race Theory posits a worldview that is daily used In civil discourse, being championed or demonized by media outlets, and is currently making Its way into the public school systems. You have youtube channels bent on hunting down all the "woke pastors" and you have leading evangelical denominations saying that CRT offers a helpful worldview for Christians to engage with. But what exactly does Critical Race Theory teach? And are the tenants of CRT biblical? In this episode, my buddy Ryan from Unsafe Media will be with us to discuss Critical Race Theory and help you understand this worldview with a biblical mindset. 

Now, we are primarily a theology podcast. As a theology podcast, I have avoided producing a bunch of content on Critical Race Theory, as I thought it was outside of our lane. However, the more I studied Critical Race Theory I realized that there are claims made by coming in the CRT movement that has radical theological implications. So without further ado, I hope you enjoy this episode of The Remnant Radio

title: Do We Interview False Teachers? Why Remnant Radio Interviews Controversial Leaders!
description:
Do We Interview False Teachers? Why Remnant Radio Interviews Controversial Leaders!

We are often asked, ‚Äúwhy do you interview all these false teachers‚Äù. Questions, or rather, accusations like these are often lobbed at us because of the false binary pushed by many heretic hunting ministries. Either you are perfectly orthodox or you are a rank heretic. These binaries are further crystallized when we begin to interview those who are often Identified as NAR leaders. However, we think there is a lot more nuance, shades of gray if you will, between a heretic and a sound teacher. Many in the chat, and on our Facebook posts were calling for a public denouncement of Bill Johnson, Mike Bickle, and Todd White. Though we may disagree with these men on various issues, no one on our team is ready to cry ‚Äúheretic‚Äù. So in this episode of The Remnant Radio, we explain where we stand theologically with guys like Bill Johnson, Mike Bickle, and Todd White. This is not a critique of their ministries, this isn't an attack on what they practice, this video is an attempt at an objective examination of their teachings and practices in order to explain why we think they fall under the banner of ‚Äúorthodox‚Äù.

title: The NAR Debate! Randy Clark Responds To Dr. Doug Geivett and Holly Pivec
description:
As many of you know, we are charismatic. But we hold a position on the New Apostolic Reformation (NAR) that is not held among many Charismatics. In fact, we probably hold a mediated position between theologians like Dr. Randy Clark and Dr. Michael Brown and those views held by Dr. Doug Geivett and Holly Pivec.

We think the New Apostolic Reformation is a helpful category when trying to identify especially harmful charismatic movements. On the other hand, "NAR" has become the new charismatic slur meant to insult and malign, and this is entirely unhelpful. As we see it, the category Is only helpful when it is applied to individuals and organizations that actually fit the pre-determined qualifications.

Last year we hosted a wonderful conversation with Dr. Doug Geivett and Holly Pivec covering their book "A New Apostolic Reformation? A Biblical Response to a Worldwide Movement." It was after this video that we were soon introduced to Dr. Randy Clark. Randy has been collecting data from Apostolic movements that he believes refutes many of the claims made by Doug and Holly. We anticipated having him on last year, but some of the surveys were not complete. In order to make a compelling case, we waited until all the data could be compiled.

That being said, THE WAIT IS OVER! Dr. Randy Clark Is making his debut appearance on the Remnant Radio Tomorrow at 4PM CST. Make sure to share the link around. It is promised to be an exciting program!

title: Is There A Difference Between OT & NT Prophecy?
description:
Among continuationists, there are two primary views of prophecy. The more widely held position is the discontinuity view. This perspective teaches that the nature of prophecy shifted from the Old Testament to the New Testament. In the Old Testament, prophets spoke infallibly, while in the New Testament, prophets could speak with the possibility of partial‚Äîor even complete‚Äîerror.

The second position is the continuity view. This view maintains that prophecy has always been fallible, both in the Old and New Testaments. However, when God‚Äôs words were recorded in Scripture‚Äîincluding prophetic writings‚Äîthey were preserved infallibly.

Today, we‚Äôll be examining both of these positions.

title: The Healing Ministry of Charles Spurgeon
description:
Did you know that Charles Spurgeon saw not hundreds but thousands of healings as he prayed for the sick? Well, I had no clue! Paul King was the first person I ever heard speak of Charles Spurgeon's healing ministry. Turns out, it really is a thing! "The Life of Charles Haddon Spurgeon: The worlds great preacher" by Russell Conwell Published in 1892 gives details of these healing testimonies. 

Let me be clear, Charles Spurgeon was not a flaming charismatic, or card-carrying pentecostal. This guy was a 19th-century particular baptist. Yet his life seems marked by supernatural healings and what most charismatics would call a genuine gift of prophecy. So in this episode, we won't be trying to claim that Spurgeon was somehow a charismatic forefather, rather will be examining his life, teaching, and practice on healing and prophecy in order to learn from his example.

title: Explaining The Dark Night Of The Soul: With Josh Hoffert
description:
The dark night of the soul is mystical language that speaks to a specific stage in someone's spiritual journey where they undergo divinely inspired difficulty that forces them to grow into greater intimacy with Christ and subsequently have a more robust view of their own responsibility and role in the world. This Dark Night Of The Soul is an opportunity for individuals to find profound purpose and pursuit of God‚Äôs presence through their pain. This pain is an instrument of God's sovereignty used to carve away the dross of our careers, relationships, dreams, and personal identity. Job had his trials, David hid in caves from King Saul, Paul had his thorn in the flesh, these deep moments of trial and pain were all used to bring them to greater intimacy and dependency on God while revealing to them a greater awareness of their purpose in the world. Often in these moments of intense trial, it feels as if God has abandoned us, clearly, in the case of David, Job, and Paul this was not the case. In fact, for those who pushed through the trial, as they did, there was greater intimacy with God found on the other side. From Saint Ammonas in the 4th Century to Saint John of The Cross in the 16th-century, contemplatives have been writing about this "dark night of the soul" to help those weary pilgrims endure the trail in order that they may obtain a precious reward. In this episode, Josh Hoffert is coming on the program to unpack the biblical, historical, and practical applications that these teachings have for us today!

Lastly, we talk about "THE Antichrist" and whether he is this perfect archetype of evil incarnate, Or if he is an actual person? Hope you enjoy.

title: Christianity vs Naturalism with Gavin Ortlund
description:
It has never been more important to articulate the wonder and enchantment of the Christian message. Yet the traditional approaches of apologetics are often outmoded in an age of profound disenchantment and distraction, unable to meet this pressing need. Gavin makes the case that Christianity offers a compelling explanatory framework for making sense of our world. However, in that framework, we ought to appeal to the mind but also to the heart and the imagination as we articulate the beauty of the gospel. In this video, we will be giving the classical arguments that disprove naturalism while suggesting that deism makes better sense of beauty, the uniformity in the laws of nature, conscious thought, and more.

title: Word of Faith Vs Men of Faith: Alternatives to WOF Doctrine From Christian History With Paul King
description:
Word of Faith Vs Men of Faith: Alternatives to WOF Doctrine From Christian History With Paul King

As Charismatics ourselves we are often labeled Word of Faith because we believe in the gifts. As Christians who call out some of the errors in the Word of Faith movement, there is a common assumption among those in the WOF that we are cessationists. However, we want to be men FULL OF FAITH! I want God to be Glorified in my life through healing, if God would have it I would love to see more healings than Amy Simple McPherson and John G Lake. If it would grow me in my faith toward God, and fruitfulness in ministry, I want to have crazier stories of provision than Kenneth Copeland and Jessie Duplantis. That being said, the testimonies do not justify the doctrines. Are there alternatives to WOF Doctrines from Christian History? Are there Men and Women who were marked by provision and miraculous power who were faithful in proclaiming orthodox doctrine? Well, In this video Paul King is with us to discuss the Word of Faith VS Men of Faith. We will be looking at three extremely Influential men George Muller, Hudson Taylor, and Charles Spurgeon. These men were marked by supernatural provision and the miraculous working of God's power while never compromising the orthodox Christian doctrine. Our goal is to compare and contrast the WOF with these historic Men of Faith so that we can point our WOF brothers to alternative examples in Christian history. Paul King has some great insights, can't wait for our talk.

In this episode, we will be revisiting the physics of heaven, courts of heaven, traveling to heaven, and maybe even prosperity gospel stuff.

title: KUNDALINI Spirits in the Church? üêç  üßò  üêç
description:
Today we are talking about the infamous Kundalini Spirit! Are there Kundalini Spirits in the Church? Well in this episode we will be discussing the Henduistic teachings on the Kundalini. "Why" you may ask. Well, it appears that some of the charismatic shakings, falling, and astatic speech seams to resemble what is called a Kundalini Awakening. Is it possible that there is a false spirit in these charismatic churches, or could there be an alternative explanation?

Well, What is Kundalini Exactly?
The earliest record we have of Kundalini yoga comes from the Yoga-kundalini Upanishad from around 1100 AD. Breaking the name down will help you understand what Kundalini yoga is. Again, the word yoga means to unite or yoke oneself with Brahman (God). Kundalini is a type of psycho-spiritual energy. According to the Yoga-kundalini Upanishad, inside of every person is a type of life force energy called Kundalini also called Prana. The goal of a Kundalini yogi is to move the energy from the base of the spine up to a spot between the eyes, and in doing so one will yoke with God (Brahman). The prana (life force energy) is coiled around the spine, and through ‚Äúthe practice of the restraint of prƒÅna, the coiled ku·πá·∏çalinƒ´ becomes straight.‚Äù
