title: Healing Evangelism Without Repentance?: Discussion with Will Hart.
description:
My new Friend Will Hart is coming on today to address the concerns many have about the evangelistic ministry of those charismatics who emphasize healing. Some say that Charismatic leaders emphasize health, wealth, and prosperity while neglecting gospel preaching. Namely repentance of sin and faith in God. But is this true? Do charismatic leaders preach "healing" while neglecting a message of repentance? It certainly has happened, but IDK that it is fair to say that it's normative.  

And Frankly, who better to discuss "healing evangelism" than Will Hart. If you Don't Know, In 2016, Heidi & Rolland Baker asked Will to take over as Iris Global's CEO. In addition to running a Global missions organization, Traveling, and speaking across the world, Will also finds time to pursue a master's degree in theology. So we have a theologically minded, evangelistically driven, charismatic guy, where else on the internet can you find conversations like this? 

Seriously though, Last year I had the privilege of going on Will's podcast. Since then it has been my privilege to get to know Will. Below are actual texts I received from Will in the last year.

"Things have exploded in northern Mozambique with war and some of the most brutal killings and tortures I have ever heard. Last week the city of Palma was overrun and internationals were killed as well." ....."Just flying back from Mozambique, thanks for praying for my trip. It was the craziest shocking trip I have ever been on. Sat with pastors who have lost everything, their children tortured and beheaded.".....

Will is not a prosperity preacher who spouts "give to get" in countries of impoverished people. Will is on the front lines of actual martyrdom preaching the Gospel boldly as Jesus performs miracles through his servants. This episode is going to be Dope, Don't miss it!

description:
Why Can't Christians Heal Everyone in a Hospital?  üè• If Charismatic Christians believe in the gift of healing, why can't they just go to the children's hospital and heal everyone inside? Isn't it inconsistent of Charismatics to claim that "God can heal" and not be able to perform healings on command? Actually, I don't think so. I am compelled that the Gift of healing operates in the same way that it did in the first century. The Apostles were able to heal some and not others.  As a charismatic myself I find it necessary to answer this question that I hear lobbed my way with great frequency. In this episode, I explain why charismatic Christians can't heal everyone, and why that is consistent with acts of the apostles in the first century.

title: Do Christians become Gods? Explaining Theosis with Michael Reardon
description:
Do Christians become Gods? Explaining Theosis with Michael Reardon

What does it mean to be a partaker of the divine nature? What does it mean to have the life of Jesus manifest in our bodies? What does it mean to grow up into mature manhood, to the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ? Well, the ancient church called it Theosis. In short, theosis is the deification of the Church. But in what way and to what end is the church deified? As an evangelical protestant, hearing the phrase ‚Äúdeification‚Äù causes an involuntary Gag reflex deep within me. However, after a good bit of study, I don‚Äôt think the doctrine of ‚Äúsanctification‚Äù is sufficient to express all that Christ has provided for us. There may be something in the doctrine of theosis that evangelical protestants may want to rediscover. 

In this episode, my new friend Michael Reardon is with us to discuss the doctrine of Theosis, with a special emphasis on Ecclesiological Theosis. Michael is the Professor of Biblical Languages and Religious Thought at Canada Christian College in Ontario. I had the privilege of sitting in on Michael‚Äôs presentation at ETS this year and thought he would be great to have on the show.

title: The Gospel of Mark Chapter 1: With Dr. Craig Keener
description:
The Gospel of Mark Chapter 1: With Dr. Craig Keener

In this episode of the Gospel of Mark, Dr. Craig Keener breaks down chapter 1. We ask Dr. Keener questions like "What does it mean to be "son of God"? Did Mark misquote Isaiah? and what literary devices is Mark employing to draw our attention to the fulfillment of the messianic prophecies?". Additionally, we discuss baptism, the empowerment by the Spirit, the confrontation of the devil, and the proclamation of the kingdom of God.

title: What Is Church Discipline & How Do We Do It?
description:
In this episode we define church discipline as "a form of punishment practiced publicly in the body of Christ aimed at the restoration of a church member that is in active rebellion against God‚Äôs word and commands. Church discipline is not the prohibition of an individual from attending meetings or church gatherings, rather it is a formal act of removing someone from church membership thus prohibiting them from partaking of the sacramental rights of believers for their own good and God‚Äôs Glory." We dive into the popular teachings of Matthew 18 where Jesus explicitly teaches church discipline and 1 Corinthians 5 where Paul explicitly practices church discipline. This is a much-needed show in the west, where our houses of worship have become social clubs due to a lack of church discipline.

title: Training In The Gifts: Panel Discussion with Matt Chandler, Jack Deere, Sam Storms, & Jeff Wells
description:
Training In The Gifts: Panel Discussion with Matt Chandler, Jack Deere, Sam Storms, & Jeff Wells

This panel discussion comes from our time at WoodsEdge Church at their Pursuit Conference. The Pursuit Conference is a pastors conference geared toward training pastors on how to train their churches in the gifts of the Spirit. This panel does not tackle the deep theological questions of the gifts, rather it was meant to dive into the practice outworkings of the gifts of the Spirt in a local church. We want to give pastors on-ramps on how they can encourage their churches to practice and train the gifts of the Spirit in their churches in safe and obtainable ways.  This was just a perfect collection of friends to accomplish that task. Sam Storms and Jack Deere are both spiritual gifts vets who have been training churches and establishing a healthy culture of gifts for decades, while Matt Chandler and Jeff Wells are comparatively, new at developing this culture in their local Churches. We were honored to host this panel. We look forward to doing it again!

title: Gnosticizing Scripture: Finding Deeper and more "Spiritual Meaning" In Scripture
description:
What happens when one decides to find a deeper, more spiritual meaning behind a given text, not only a meaning that is profound but specifically unique to your circumstances? Well, you gnosticize that mug. 

Look, I believe God still speaks today outside of scripture. I don't think that it is impossible or even unlikely that God would speak to you as you read the Bible. However, there has been this novel form of preaching and Bible reading that has been circulating In the charismatic movement that looks a great deal like Gnosticism, and this kind of reading Is really hurting people. 

We have no plans of bride bashing or bullying people who preach differently than we do. but we do hope to bring up some serious concerns and we hope that it can help those who are not even aware of the dangers.

title: Kenosis: What Did Christ Empty?
description:
Kenosis: What Did Christ Empty? - It just seemed too incredible for modern rational and ‚Äòscientific‚Äô people to believe that Jesus Christ could be truly human and fully, absolutely God at the same time. The kenosis theory began to sound more and more like an acceptable way to say that (in some sense) Jesus was God, but a kind of God who had for a time given up some of his Godlike qualities, those that were most difficult for people to accept in the modern world. Charismatic pastors and teachers have not made the conversation any easier. Guys like Todd White and Bill Johnson have used some pretty novel language when attempting to articulate kenosis theory, which has mucked up the conversation with every discernment ministry crying "heresy". Hopefully, this episode can shed some light on the kenosis debate and hopefully help level heads prevail.

description:
Discerning Dreams & Discerning Visions With The Church Fathers

There are tons of videos on youtube discussing novel ways of interpreting dreams and visions. Some are helpful, some are a spiritualized reading of Freud, and others are just nonsense. Whatever is a charismatic to do?

Is there a pattern in discerning visions from God or the visions from a devil? all this and more will be tackled in this episode of The Remnant Radio.

title: NAR Vocabulary and Terminology
description:
NAR Vocabulary and Terminology

The New Apostolic Reformation is not a formal organization of clandestine churches but a category used by some to identify a specific sect of Charismatics. Unfortunately, the NAR is often used by heretic hunters as a derogatory catch-all for ‚Äúdumb charismatics that we don't like‚Äù. 
However, as we have engaged with a lot of charismatic literature, we find that it is a helpful category for identifying a specific branch of hyper-charismatics. Not a group of people who are ‚Äúnot Christian‚Äù rather a group of Christians who hold certain extra-biblical charismatic beliefs that we believe are harmful and or a distraction for the mission of the Church. We have done episodes in the past dealing with specific NAR practices, teachings, and doctrine, but in this episode, we will specifically be tackling the NAR vocabulary. Alignment, Portals, Realms, Apostolic favor, Kingdom Finances, Strategic Spiritual Warfare, and more!

title: How the Church Fathers Balanced Liturgy & Spontaneity
description:
How the Church Fathers Balanced Liturgy & Spontaneity

You ever been in one of those services where the Spirit of God was so tangible that the staff canceled the sermon, the offering, and communion so that we could continue in worship? Well back in my pentecostal days, it wasn't all that uncommon for us to do just that. But is it a good thing to throughout the liturgy (order of service) for spontaneity? On the other hand, should we be so liturgical that there is never room for spontaneous expressions of worship? Oddly enough the Church fathers might have an answer for us. 

In this episode Josh Hoffert, Matthew Esquivel, and Father Ron Drummond are doing a survey of the church fathers, looking for their balance of liturgy and spontaneity. Going to be a fun episode full of flag-waving, tambourine playing, and shofar blowing. Hope you guys enjoy it!

title: The Nephilim and The Son's of God
description:
The Nephilim and The Son's of God

The Bible has a whole host of characters who are hard to understand from the western mind. One of these characters are the "sons of God" another is the "Nephilim". In this episode we are answering the question "who are the Nephilim and The Son's of God". Mystery and debate surround the Sons of God in scripture. Are the Sons of God descendants of Seth, are the sons of God fallen angels, or are the Sons of God some kind of ancient kings. The questions spiral further out of control when you read Genesis 6 and see the Nephilim. Are the Nephilim the giants spoken of through mythology, did the Nephilim emerge from the relations of the sons of God and the daughters of men? Or were the Nephilim only landmarks for the reader to know when the events of the Son's of God happened. All this and more are covered in this episode of The Remnant Radio. Hope you enjoy it.

description:
The Teachings of John Wesley with Dr. Billy Abraham

In this episode acclaimed Wesley scholar Dr. William Abraham joined us to discuss the sermons and teachings of John Wesley. Dr. Abraham is a brilliant scholar and lively personality. I hope you all enjoy this episode.

title: How Do People Get Demonized? Occult Practices, Idolatry & Blasphemy
description:
The Remnant Radio tackles the complex topic of demonization, exploring how individuals open themselves up to demonic oppression through occult practices, idolatry, and blasphemy. Host Joshua Lewis welcomes Michael Miller to discuss the biblical understanding of demonic influence, offering practical advice, and personal anecdotes. This episode provides listeners with insights into discerning demonic activity, the power of deliverance ministry, and the importance of a faith-filled response to spiritual warfare.

0:00: Introduction
5:48: Defining demonization, discussing the scripture, and distinguishing from mental illness.
10:51: Occult practices and their connection to demonization, sharing personal stories.
17:15: What to do when you‚Äôre in a deliverance situation.
24:00: Idolatry as an open door to demonic influence.
37:57: Defining blasphemy and speaking against God and the Holy Spirit.
55:00: Wrap-up

title: How Did the Apostles Die? An Interview With Dr. Sean McDowell
description:
In our interview with Dr. Sean McDowell, one of the top 100 apologists, we'll explore how each of the apostles met their end. Dr. McDowell brings his deep knowledge and research to the table as we explore church history and traditions surrounding the deaths of these foundational figures of the Christian faith. From martyrdom to miraculous survival, we'll discuss the powerful and sometimes surprising stories that have shaped Christian history and what these accounts mean for believers today. Don't miss this compelling conversation on the legacy and sacrifice of the apostles.

title: How to Lead a Church Into the Gifts: With Jack Deere & Jeff Wells
description:
Jack Deere & Jeff Wells along with Michael Rowntree address how they discovered the gifts of the Spirit and the best practices to lead and pastor a church into the spiritual gifts. In transitioning a church body from a cessationist to a continuationist church, they examine how pastors can build a healthy culture for exhibiting the gifts and what the Bible says about orderly use of the gifts of the Spirit. Jack Deere, formerly an associate professor of Old Testament at Dallas Theological Seminary, is a writer and lecturer who speaks on friendship with God and on the gifts of the Holy Spirit. He is the author of the bestselling book, Surprised by the Power of the Spirit. Jeff Wells is the founding pastor of WoodsEdge Community Church in Houston, Texas.

#remnantradio #giftsofthespirit #holyspirit 

üåêüìß Visit our Website & Subscribe to our Newsletter: https://www.theremnantradio.com

title: What Does a Healthy Church Look Like: With Mark Dever
description:
Join us this week on The Remnant Radio as we sit down with the esteemed Pastor Mark Dever, a man whose profound writings have deeply impacted our host‚Äôs journey of faith. In this compelling episode, we delve into the critical yet often misunderstood topic of church discipline, exploring its pivotal role in nurturing the health and vibrancy of the church.

üõ°Ô∏è Why Church Discipline? Discover why Pastor Dever insists that discipline is indispensable in preserving the church's purity and preventing it from mirroring the secular world around us.

‚ù§Ô∏è A Process of Love and Restoration: Learn about the delicate, redemptive nature of church discipline. It's not about authoritarian measures but fostering a slow, loving process aimed at reconciliation with God and fellow believers.

ü§ù The Foundation of Community: Understand why such discipline necessitates church membership, emphasizing the church's duty to lovingly correct and guide, ensuring a community rooted in regeneration and mutual accountability.

üôè Regenerate Church Membership: A cornerstone for a thriving church‚Äîfind out how it empowers members to actively engage in one another's spiritual lives, offering support, prayer, and accountability.

This episode is not just a discussion; it's a journey into the heart of what makes a church not just a congregation, but a family united in Christ. Whether you're a church leader, a member of a faith community, or simply curious about the dynamics of church health, Pastor Dever‚Äôs insights offer invaluable wisdom for all.

Tune in to The Remnant Radio. Be part of this enlightening conversation that promises to challenge, inspire, and transform your understanding of church life and leadership.

0:00 Introduction
0:47 Interview with Pastor Mark Dever
2:46 Crowdfunding and Support
4:14 Planned Content and Series
8:23 Introduction to Pastor Mark Dever‚Äôs Ministry
9:30 Impact of Mark Dever‚Äôs Written Works
15:56 Transition to Church Discipline
16:40 Church Discipline in the Old Testament
18:18 Church Discipline in the New Testament
20:25 Process of Church Discipline
24:09 Importance of Church Membership
26:25 Regenerate Church Membership
29:14 Role of Members in Church Discipline

title: Molinism: With Dr. Kenneth Keathley
description:
Molinism, named after 16th-century Spanish Jesuit theologian Luis de Molina, is a view about the providence of God in light of human free will. Prominent contemporary Molinists are William Lane Craig, Alfred Freddoso, Thomas Flint, Kenneth Keathley, Dave Armstrong, and Tim Stratton. The view affirms a strong notion of God's control of events in the world, alongside an equally firm view of human freedom.

title: What Was Latter Rain Movement: With Jon Bunn
description:
What Was Latter Rain Movement: With Jon Bunn

The Latter Rain Movement had its beginnings in the years following World War II and was contemporary with the evangelical awakening led by Billy Graham, as well as the Healing Revival of Oral Roberts, Jack Coe, and William Branham. In the fall of 1947, several leaders of the small Pentecostal, 'Sharon Orphanage and Schools in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, who were hungry for God were inspired to fast and pray and wait on God after visiting Rev. Branham's healing campaign that was held in the Exhibition Garden in Vancouver, Canada, where four to five thousand people packed inside to witness people being healed. They had never seen anything like it before and those at the Sharon Schools began to fast and pray for more outpourings of the Holy Spirit. Later that year, groups organized large revival events, and news quickly swept across Canada and the United States, influencing many Pentecostal believers.

As the revival died down after a few years, those who had been changed by the doctrine formed various groups which became known as "The Latter Rain" (Movement). The Latter Rain strongly emphasized relational networks over organizational structure. In addition, the term Latter Rain has become somewhat of a pejorative label; therefore, many ministers who were influenced by it are reluctant to make this well known. They often choose to emphasize only formal participation. Much of the movement, along with elements of the Healing Revival, slowly dissolved into parts of the larger Charismatic movement.

title: Jeremiah chapter 23: the False Prophets in Scripture
Healing and Prophecy: An Interview with Jack Deere
description:
Healing and Prophecy: An Interview with Jack Deere

Join us for an enlightening episode of The Remnant Radio, where we dive deep into the transformative journey of Jack Deere, from a staunch cessationist to a fervent believer in the ongoing gifts of the Spirit. In this captivating interview, Jack Deere opens up about his personal voyage of discovery, sparked by a challenging testimony of healing that shook the very foundations of his beliefs.

üî• From Cessationism to Embracing the Spirit's Gifts: Discover how Jack Deere's encounter with Dr. John White's miraculous testimony led him to question and ultimately abandon his cessationist views, embarking on a faith-filled journey towards understanding the gifts of the Spirit.

üëâ A Testimony that Challenges: Delve into the story of Dr. John White, whose experience with divine healing prompted Deere to reexamine the healing narratives within the New Testament, challenging long-held beliefs and opening his eyes to the reality of God's active presence in the world today.

‚ö° Revisiting the New Testament: Join us as Deere shares his insights into the healing stories of the New Testament, unveiling the truth that there is no scriptural foundation for the belief that miracles were intended solely to authenticate the apostles as reliable teachers.

üí° Miracles: Confirming the Message, Not the Messengers: Explore the profound understanding that miracles are not just signs to validate the messengers of the Gospel but powerful affirmations of the message itself, designed to draw people closer to the truth and love of God.

‚ú® A Message of Hope and Healing: This episode is not just an exploration of theological transformation but a testament to the enduring power of faith, hope, and the miraculous workings of the Holy Spirit in our lives today.

Whether you're a believer in the gifts of the Spirit, a skeptic of miraculous healing, or somewhere in between, this interview with Jack Deere offers a compelling look at the biblical basis for miracles and the impact of experiencing the supernatural firsthand. Tune in to be inspired, challenged, and perhaps, see your own beliefs in a new light.

Don't miss this powerful episode of The Remnant Radio, where we continue to bridge divides, build community, and explore the diverse spectrum of Christian faith across the globe. Subscribe and share with friends who are on their own journey of faith and understanding.

title: Are Christians Anti-Science? Or are Christians Anti-Naturalist?
description:
Are Christians Anti-Science?

Description:
Join us on Remnant Radio for a riveting discussion with Ken Fish, a renowned speaker and theologian, as we delve into the crucial topics of anti-Scientism, Naturalism, Rationalism, and the profound depths of the Christian worldview. In this enlightening episode, we explore the intellectual shift in the West towards an anti-intellectualist stance, examining its detrimental impact on the Gospel's transmission and acceptance.

Ken Fish brings his vast knowledge and insightful perspectives to dissect how Enlightenment ideals, historical events like the Scopes Monkey Trial, and certain tendencies within Christian subculture have contributed to a growing rift between faith and reason. This conversation illuminates the often misunderstood relationship between Christianity and rational thought, challenging the prevailing naturalistic framework that seeks to explain away the supernatural.

ü§î Discover the distinct differences between Rationalism and Naturalism, and understand why they are not the ultimate adversaries of Christian thought.
üåç Unpack the limitations of Naturalism, which insists on natural explanations for all phenomena, and see how it falls short in accounting for the full spectrum of human experience.
ü§ù Learn how Christianity and Rationalism can coexist, complementing rather than conflicting with each other.
üôè Witness the discussion on supernatural occurrences that defy naturalistic explanations, affirming the reality of the spiritual realm.
üß† Debate the reliance of Naturalism on sensory input for validation, and the implications for understanding reality beyond the physical.

This episode is not just an intellectual journey; it's a heartfelt exploration of how embracing a Christian worldview enriches our understanding of the world, challenges the status quo, and brings us closer to the truth. Ken's engaging discussion and our deep dive into these topics reveal the vibrancy of faith in dialogue with reason, offering fresh perspectives for believers and skeptics alike.

Whether you're a long-time follower of Christ, a seeker of truth, or someone navigating the complexities of faith and intellect, this episode promises a compelling narrative that bridges divides and invites reflection.

Enjoy this thought-provoking journey as we seek to reclaim the intellectual richness of the Christian faith, moving beyond the confines of scientism and naturalism. Blessings to you as you join us in this exploration.

#RemnantRadio #KenFish #ChristianWorldview #AntiScientism #FaithAndReason #Enlightenment #Supernatural #RationalismVsNaturalism #TheologyPodcast

Remember to like, share, and subscribe to Remnant Radio for more insightful discussions with pastors and teachers from diverse Christian traditions around the globe. Your support helps us continue these important conversations.

title: An Interview With Francis Chan
description:
An Interview With Francis Chan

What do the POPE, TODD WHITE, AND HANK HANAGRAPH all have in common? They all know Francis Chan. Francis is a riddle wrapped in an enigma that has caught the attention of the conservative evangelical movement. As a graduate of Masters seminary and a pastor of a thriving megachurch, Francis Chan was a rising star in the conservative evangelical movement. He was a regular guest to the Passion conference, Desiring God, and IHOP's One thing, Francis was one of the most popular names on the conference circuit and amongst publishers. 

That is until he started making decisions that were "self-sabotaging" in the eyes of western evangelicalism. Francis left his megachurch to start a network of house churches that were centered around authentic discipleship. Only to leave his now thriving home churches to do missions in China. All the while Francis begins to share stages with those on the evangelical blacklist. Who is Francis and what is driving his consciousness into the spotlight of controversy?

In this interview, we discuss everything with Francis Chan. We ask "is Francis Chan Catholic? What does Francis believe about Justification, Are Benny Hinn and Francis Chan BFF's" and more. Hope you all enjoy it.

title: What is the New Perspective on Paul: With Matthew Bates
description:
What is the New Perspective on Paul: With Matthew Bates

In this episode of Remnant Radio, Josh and Michael Rowntree interview Matthew Bates on the New Perspective on Paul.

The typical Protestant understanding of ‚Äújustification by grace through faith alone‚Äù is founded on the Protestants interpretations of the Pauline letters of Galatians and Romans. Both juxtapose law and flesh against the faith and Spirit. The historic Protestant position suggests that Paul is attempting to correct a Jewish misunderstanding of justification, a justification merited by works. 

However, the ‚ÄúNew Perspective on Paul‚Äù suggests that the issue is not about justification by works. Proponents of ‚Äúthe new perspective‚Äù such as E.P. Sanders suggests that first-century Palestinian Judaism was not a "legalistic community," nor was it oriented to "salvation by works." But that the issue Paul is addressing, is an issue of requiring gentiles to become Jewish converts before they can have access to the blessings of Christ. According to Sanders, Paul does not address good works in general but instead questions only observances such as circumcision, dietary laws, and Sabbath laws, which were the "boundary markers" that set the Jews apart from the other nations.

title: Testing the Prophets: Testing the Prophecies Given in 2020
description:
Testing the Prophets: Testing the Prophecies Given in 2020 - We believe in the gifts of the Spirit. But 2020 has proven that the prophets have been getting out of hand. Hundreds of prophetic words were given in 2020. And the Prophetic words given in 2020 were vague, wrong, and in some cases false. In this 8 Hour Marathon, some of the leading continuationist scholars review prophetic words given in 2020. We are not judging prophetic ministry or judging the prophets. Our goal is to test each prophetic word on its own and give our audience the tools to judge these prophetic words moving forward. Testing prophecies given in 2020 won't be easy, but it is necessary. Scripture commands us not to despise prophecy, but test it: cling to what is good, and reject that which is evil. We will be looking for good prophecies given in 2020, and we will be looking for bad prophecies given in 2020.

title: Demystifying the New Age Jesus with Steven Bancarz
description:
In this episode, former New Age practitioner (now Christian believer) Steven Bancarz comes back on the show to discuss how the New age understands "Christ Consciousness." 

Christ Consciousness is a New Age philosophy that suggests one can come to an awareness of the higher self as part of a universal system. Although it can be interpreted in a number of ways, a common understanding is that Christ Consciousness is the state of consciousness in which a person has found self-realization and unity with God or the Divine. But why do they call it "Christ Consciousness"? Well the New Age groups say Jesus became Christ when he came to an awareness of the Higher Self. They would say that we, like Jesus, can also become Christs when we become aware of our divinity.

In this Episode, Steven Bancarz demystifies the New Age Jesus, by comparing the new age claims of Jesus's Christ consciousness with the biblical text. 

Hope you enjoy it.

title: Todd White: was Jesus fully God? (Does Todd White believe the Kenosis heresy?)
description:
Todd White: was Jesus fully God? (the Kenosis debate)

The way we define Kenosis has such a massive impact on our Christology that it can determine whether you are ignorant, a heretic, or an orthodox Christian. For those who claim that Christ performed healings and exorcisms through his divinity come dangerously close to subordinationism (partial-Arianism). Because the bible says Christ was empowered by the Spirit to perform miracles, if these miracles were done through Christ divinity it would logically suggest that Christ divine nature was lacking and needed the empowerment of the Spirit. 

If we error on the other side we come dangerously close to full-blown Arianism. because if we say Jesus stopped being God then you have a person of the trinity that does not share in the same essence (homoousios) as the Father and the Spirit. Furthermore if the Christ Jesus did everything as a man our salvation is in jeopardy, for only God can forgive sins, and only the infinite value of God's sacrificial death on the cross would be sufficient to atone for the sins of the World.

How we describe the hypostatic union (Christ being fully God and Fully Man) is an essential Christian doctrine that has been believed and practiced by every Christian for the past 2,000 Years.  If you would like to study this more I would encourage you to watch our episodes on the Chalcedonian definition, and the Nicene Creed. 

Also for those having a hard time understanding the language between classical Pentecostals and reformed evangelicals on the Subject of Kenosis I would advise this clip from an interview between James White and Dr. Michael Brown. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tuFhJm0v6-s&ab_channel=JoshParker

title: Generational Curses and Demonic Strongholds
description:
1) What is the most common teaching of generational curses
2) Is there any validity to sin temptations being transmitted through the family line
3) Is there any validity to demonic bondage being transmitted through the family line

Often times (not always) Generational curses are defined as "a negative pattern manifesting in you, and or, your family due to demonic activity that was granted access by the unrepentant sins of your ancestors". However, there is a major problem with this definition. There is no mention of demons in the "typical generational curse" proof texts. In Numbers 14:17-18 and Exodus 20:4-6 we find God is the one bringing the curse not demons. Why is God cursing man? Well, Scripture tells us that we are cursed if we do not abide by everything written in the Law. So by breaking God's law we are placed under a curse from God.

"But what about the Christian?" you may ask. Well, Christ took our place and became a curse for us that the curse of the Lay may be removed from us. Praise God! But now we get into the nitty-gritty of it all. Is there a demonic activity that can be transmitted generationally? Can our habitual unrepented sins, somehow be transmitted to our children? Well if you want to know that you will have to watch the video. Hope you guys all enjoy it.

title: Marcionism and Modern Marcionism
description:
Marcionism and Modern Marcionism

If you are not familiar with Marcion, he is best known for his work on the text and canon of the Bible. He rejected the OT as a Christian book and collected the earliest known Christian canon, composed of an abbreviated version of Luke's Gospel and ten edited Pauline epistles (lacking the Pastorals). He presented his theological views in the Antitheses, in which he set out contradictions between the OT and the NT. His works do not survive, so his positions must be reconstructed from the refutations made by his opponents, the fullest of which is Tertullian's five books Against Marcion.

Marcion was convinced that Paul was the only true apostle and that the original twelve, by ‚ÄòJudaizing', became false apostles. Galatians was placed first in his collection of Paul's letters. The opening words of the Antitheses, ‚ÄòO wealth of riches! rapture, power, amazement! seeing that there can be nothing to say about it, or to imagine about it, or to compare to it!' expresses his wonder before the Pauline gospel of grace. From Paul, Marcion deduced an exaggerated contrast between law and gospel. In agreement with his contemporary Aquila of Pontus, he practiced a literal interpretation of Scripture, rejecting all allegory. Marcion went far beyond Paul in concluding that there are two Gods: the God of the OT, the Creator, who is a God of law and justice and who predicted the Jewish Messiah; and the previously unknown God of the NT, the Father of Jesus Christ, who is a God of mercy and salvation.

Unfortunately, these teachings live on in the body of Christ today. Sections of scripture, books of scripture, and at times entire testaments of scripture are looked at as inferior, uninspired, or in some extreme cases even considered fallible. So we discuss historic Marcionism so that we can have the discernment to detect the modern nuance of modern Marcionism.

title: The Imago Dei: How bearing God's image could change culture
description:
The Imago Dei is a theological category that asserts that human beings are created in the image and likeness of God. The Imago die was at the center of the egalitarian liberation of women across the globe, it was the foundation of William Wilberforce's abolishing of slavery, and today is the missing ingredient to the necessary cultural revolution in America.

In this episode of the Remnant Radio, Josh and Michael discuss 
1)the image of God in Adam & Eve
2) How the image was distorted at the fall
3) How God relates to those who bear his image
4) The image restored at regeneration
5) The responsibility of the Church and Governments in the light of the Imago Dei

title: Five points of Calvinism: With Joel Webbon
description:
Five points of Calvinism: With Joel Webbon

In this video, our friend Joel Webbon comes on to discuss the five points of Calvinism. Modern Calvinism is most often the term used for reformed soteriology (not to be confused with followers of John Calvin). Calvinism (as it relates to soteriology) is often reduced into 5 points that can be seen in the acronym T.U.L.I.P. 

Total depravity, unconditional election, limited atonement, irritable grace, and perseverance of the saints. Joel does a great job unpacking each of these points in an unreasonably short amount of time. Hope you all enjoy

title: Eastern Orthodox Theology: with Frederica Mathewes-Greene
description:
Eastern Orthodox Theology

Americans tend to divide the Christian religion into two camps: Protestant and Catholic. But there's a third branch called "Eastern Orthodox" that consists of 260 million members worldwide. Many evangelicals have converted to Eastern Orthodoxy, including "the Bible Answer Man," Hank Hanegraaf. CS Lewis found the church intriguing. Yet many evangelicals know hardly anything about it. And the mystery makes us skeptical.

A few months ago, I read a book by Frederica Mathewes-Greene about Eastern Orthodoxy. It was beautiful. Her journey took her from Catholicism to Mainline Protestantism to Charismatic to Eastern Orthodox, where she has found her home. I don't think we should be skeptical of our differences; we should be inspired by them. I think you'll be inspired by her. We're interviewing her tonight on Remnant Radio, 8:30pm Live.

title: Is Online Church Biblical
description:
Is Online Church Biblical


In this round table discussion, Matthew Esquivel, Michael David Mitchell, Dawson Jarrell, Father Ron Drummond.
Try to answer the question, Is Online Church Biblical? 

Central to this discussion are the growing numbers of churches considering continuing the practices after the quarantine even going so far as making online church the way they do church. Remanent Radio has assembled an eclectic group of ministers to discuss the practical, ethical, and doctrinal aspects of this new ‚Äúmethod‚Äù of doing church.  

The participants come from various segments of Christianity, Anglican, Methodist, Baptist, and Assemblies of God which makes for a robust and lively dialogue. From the physicality of the Christian faith to how sacramental theology can be practiced in a pandemic, no subject is left unexplored.

title: Amillennialism with Dr. Sam Storms
description:
In this episode, Dr. Sam Storms discusses the Amillennial perspective of the end times. He begins by clarifying that ‚ÄúAmillennial‚Äù is a bit of a misnomer ‚Äì since he does, in fact, believe in a Millennium. It just looks different than the ‚Äúliteralistic‚Äù view of Historic Premillennialism. On that note, he talks through the hermeneutic to employ when interpreting apocalyptic literature‚Äîhow do we know when to understand things literally or figuratively? Dr. Storms responds to the major objections to Amillennialism, he explains in detail why he is not Premillennial, and he makes a biblical case for Amillennialism. All of this is couched in his own personal journey away from Premillennialism (which his seminary taught strongly) and toward Amillennialism. If you‚Äôre interested in the end times and want to understand the biblical teaching more, you won‚Äôt want to miss this episode. Even if you don‚Äôt agree with all of Dr. Storms‚Äô points, you‚Äôll certainly find that he goes to the Bible to support his beliefs.

title: Passover 2020: with Jon Bunn & Remnant Radio
description:
Passover 2020: with Jon Bunn & Remnant Radio

Due to the coronavirus, this will be the first year in the last three years my family and I have not practiced the Passover in a church gathering. So I invited my friend Jon Bunn from the Hub DFW to came to the studio last week so we could capture Passover for those who do not want to miss out on remembering what God has done for his people. 

SEDER CELEBRATION ITEMS
For the Seder Plate: A Lamb Shank, Parsely, Horseradish, Roasted Egg, *Charoset, three pieces of Matza, a *white napkin, and Salt Water. 

You will also need two candles for the beginning of the meal on the table and a pitcher of water and a basin with a towel for the hand washing ceremony. Each guest will also need 4 cups of grape juice or wine.

*Charoset is a mixture of apples, nuts, honey, raisins, and wine and represents and is the consistency of mortar.

*The white napkin is used to wrap and hide what is called the "afikomen." Later in the meal, the children search for it and return it the head of the table for a prize or treat of some kind (If you have children present, please also include something to reward them for finding the "afikomen").


THE MEAL OF YOUR CHOICE
Feel free to make your family the dinner of your choice. Typically, chicken and nothing with yeast in it is servered about 2/3 of the way through the Seder presentation.

title: What is Contemplative Prayer?: With Matthew Esquivel
description:
In this episode of Remnant Radio, Joshua Lewis and Michael Rowntree will talk to Matthew Esquivel about ‚Äúcontemplative prayer‚Äù.  Matthew will explain contemplative prayer as understood by two spiritual heavyweights in church history; Teresa of Avila and John of the Cross. Using scripture and the guidance from Teresa and John, Matthew seeks to distinguish between the New Age views of contemplative prayer and the kind contemplative prayer within the Christain tradition. While tying this ancient practice into the ‚Äúsoaking" emphasis we see in the modern charismatic church. To do this, Matthew references the autobiography of Teresa and her first Spiritual Testimony while bringing in John‚Äôs teachings on the subject as they often complement one another. The guys will consider the practices of vocal prayer and silent prayer, looking at the different contemplatives understanding of each, while seeking to understand how we might find some balance between the two categories of prayer.

This episode will also discuss different types of "prayer" as taught by Teresa of Avila and John of the Cross. Such as the Prayer of recollection, the prayer of quiet, the prayer of rapture, And the prayer of union. As well as the different types of visions and locutions one may experience in these different types of prayer. Other topics touched on are on the role of visions, hearing God, and having supernatural encounters in one‚Äôs journey towards greater union with God.

title: Gnosticism: Why History Repeats Itself
description:
Gnosticism was an ancient cult that merged greek myth, biblical stories, and platonic philosophy into a religion that did not reflect Christianity in the slightest. However, this gnostic cult influenced much of the early church. Had it not been for Irenaus work on "Against Heresies" we would know little of Gnosticism. Fortunately, Irenaeus' work would allow us to identify the recently discovered Nag Hammadi text as gnostic literature. Books such as the gospel of Thomas, the gospel of Judas, or the secret gospel of John would have never been identified as gnostic had it not been for Irenaeus. 

Now that we know what gnosticism is, we find it shocking that we see proto (or early) gnosticism surounding us in mondern Chrisindom. In this episode we will discuss the gnostic myth, identify key theological distinctives such as dualism, antanomianism, and asseticism. Then we will conclude our episode talking about how we see these paterns in chrisindom today. Hope you enjoy.

title: Sola Scriptura: Scripture Alone With Dr. Jordan Cooper
description:
Christians ought to submit to the authority given to us by Christ, Pastors, elders, teachers, etc. But what happens when those in authority teach things contrary to the Word of God? Is there a higher court to which we can appeal? The answer is yes. The appeal is the appeal of sola scriptura. 

"Sola Scriptura" is a phrase that sounds foreign to western ears. In Latin, the phrase  means "only Scripture" or "Scripture alone." It was one of the five Solas articulated by the Protestant Reformation. 

But what is the significance of this phrase? 

Sola Scriptura is the idea that the Bible is the final authority on what Christians believe and how we live. In this video,  Dr. Jordan Cooper from the "Just & Sinner" podcast is coming on the show to help us understand the growing need for sola scriptura in our day. We will also give some biblical reasons to support Sola Scriptura and deal with some Catholic rebuttals to it. I hope you all enjoy.

Tonight we will ask questions like "How did Origen read the bible, was Origen's pattern of hermeneutics unique to the culture he lived in, and how was it that Origen's patter of hermeneutics was able to so greatly impact the early church. It is well known that Origen saw a "spiritual meaning" beyond the plain reading of the text. Is this something Christians should likewise strive for, or is this something we should avoid?" Summery of Origen‚Äôs hermeneutical approach.
Description of Origen‚Äôs hermeneutical approach.
‚ÄúHe thought that Scripture had three different, yet complementary, meanings; (1) a
literal or physical sense, (2) a moral or psychical sense, and (3) an allegorical or
intellectual sense. The threefold sense was based upon his belief in a corresponding
threefold division of mankind‚Äù (1) the physical, (2) the emotional or psychical, and
(3) the spiritual or intellectual.‚Äù

David Dockery, Biblical Interpretation (Baker Grand Rapids, 2000) 88.
Origen‚Äôs threefold division was derived from his view of humanity:
‚ÄúJust as human beings consist of body, soul and spirit, so also do the Scriptures.
The bodily sense of a text was either the historical or literal meaning. The soulish
meaning of a text contained a figurative exhortation to avoid vice and grow in
virtue. It was the moral or ethical teaching. The third level was the spiritual
meaning of Scripture. It contained the allegorical sense which was the most
profound level appropriate to God and humanity. It reveals God‚Äôs plan of salvation
through Christ‚Äôs incarnation. But it is known only to a mature group of elite
believers...‚Äù

Bradley Nassif, ‚ÄúOrigen,‚Äù Dictionary of Major Biblical Interpreters,
ed. Donald K. McKim, (Downers Grove: IVP Academic, 2007), 789
Nassif ‚Äôs full article in appendix A

Origen‚Äôs general interpretive principles:
‚ÄúFirst, every text is pregnant with profound mysteries and should be discovered
through allegory. Second, nothing should be said of God which is unworthy of
him. Third, each text was to be interpreted in the light of the rest of Scripture.
Finally, nothing contrary to the rule of faith was to be affirmed.‚Äù

Dockery, Biblical Interpretation, 89.
Dockery references church historian
Justo L. Gonzalez Analysis of
Origen‚Äôs hermeneutic.

(READ MORE)
https://theremnantradio.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Origen.pdf

If you don't know what Apostolic succession is, basically its the idea that throughout history there is an uninterrupted transmission of spiritual authority from the Apostles through successive popes and bishops, often taught by Roman Catholics friends. In part one we established where the line of Apostles has come from, and how it operates in the Anglican tradition. Looking to pick up where this one left off. 

However, our brother Keith belongs to Anglican Church. Anglicans are a protestant denomination who also participates the ancient tradition of apostolic succession. Bishop Keith Ackerman will be coming to teach us all the history about apostolic succession.

title: The Second Blessing Debate: Two Views of Spirit Baptism
description:
The Second Blessing Debate: Two Views of Spirit Baptism

In classical pentecostalism, the "second blessing" comes when the Baptism of the Spirit occurs. Within this framework this baptism is a subsequent experience following conversion, where the believer is endued with power from on high, evidenced by speaking in tongues. Pentecostals teach that All believers are entitled to and should ardently expect and earnestly seek the promise of the Father, the baptism in the Holy Spirit and fire, according to the command of our Lord Jesus Christ. 

In mainline denominations and across much of evangelicalism, the "baptism of the Spirit" is a baptism into Christ's body that occurs at the moment of salvation. Though many of the conservative evangelicals believe in the gifts of the Spirit, they do not believe that a secondary experience is necessary to be endued with power for on high. Rather Christ's salvation brought all thing necessary for a life of Godliness

Both of these positions are orthodox Christian beliefs, but only one of them is true. Representing the classical pentecostal position of "the second blessing" Pastor Todd  Barham will be giving a 15min presentation of why the classical pentecostal view is a biblical-theological view. 

Following Pastor Todd, our buddy Michael Miller will be giving a 15 min presentation on why the traditional evangelical view of "baptism of the spirit" is the correct biblical position. 

No debates, no cross-examination, 30 min of presentation and then live Q&A from the audience.  I can't wait to see where this conversation takes us. Going to be a fun night Hope you enjoy it.

title: The Abomination of Desolation: With Ken Fish
description:
The Abomination of Desolation: With Ken Fish

There are so many questions surrounding the end times. What exactly does the millennium look like, is there going to be a pre-tribulation rapture, Who is the antichrist and where will he come from? Well, our friend Ken Fish is coming on the show to answer one of the more mysterious eschatological questions, What is the abomination of desolation? Ken thinks he has the answer.

Ken tracks the prophecy from Daniel all the way into church history. The discussion spans issues of the temple mount the religion of Islam the nature of the temple as well as the sacrificial system discussed in the prophecy.  Did the Knights Templar establish or did it happen when the Dome of the rock was established in the Middle Ages?
 
Dispelling the common idea that the first reference of the prophecy was about the Seleucid king Antiochus Epiphanes IV, who ruled Palestine from 175-64 B.C. When Antiochus l came to suppress a rebellion, his forces entered the temple, he stopped the regular sacrifices, set up an idol for Zeus, and offered swine there as a sacrifice. This is an abomination because it is idolatry, and it brings desolation because it defiles the holy place at the heart of Israel. But does it fit the time line? Is it an act that was an abomination ‚Äúcausing‚Äù desolation? Ken things he has the answer

title: False Conversions
description:
False Conversions seems to be a topic of interest in the church. Some are concerned with the lack of faithfulness, others seem concerned with the lack of faith. There are groups whose sole purpose in life is to hunt down all the heretics in the world and assert their own superiority over them. Other groups don't care at all what you believe or how you live. If you say you are Christian they will give you the benefit of the doubt. 

Trying to understand these matters can be difficult. It is not our job to determine who is saved and who is not. However, if someone is lost and they are convinced they are saved, shouldn't we know how to speak truth into that space? Do you have a hard time trying to figure out who is a real convert and who is not? 

In this episode of remnant Radio, Evangelist Levi Luts will be with us. We are discussing unregenerate Christians, false conversions, and deceptive gospels that are leading people away from faith in Christ. This can be a divisive topic, but it does not need to be. Being able to identify "fake Christians" is not a means of painting a guilt target on their back. However, being able to discern who is not of the faith gives us a beautiful opportunity to speak gospel life into those spaces. This is going to be a great episode, hope you enjoy.

title: Moral Therapeutic Deism: You don't even know you are doing it
description:
We are discussing Moral Therapeutic Deism, the dangers of MTD, and how you are witnessing it every day and don't even know it.

What is your aim? Do you aspire to be a better spouse, father, mother, or coworker? Moral therapeutic deism can get you there. Just follow these 3 easy steps and it will change your whole life. Trust in yourself, work really hard, and surround yourself with others who trust themselves and who also work really hard. These self-help steps are at the core of moral therapeutic deism. 

Sound a little fishy? Unfortunately, this "do more Christianity" is pervasive in pragmatic consumerism. Somehow it has found its way into our churches. Moral therapeutic deism is waging war on the gospel and most Christians can't even detect this silent killer. So in this episode of Remnant Radio Josh Lewis and Michael Miller will explain how we can read the bible in a way that removes us from the center of the Gospel and places Christ as its cornerstone. Debunking moral therapeutic deism isn't hard, but be warned, once you learn what it is you won't be able to stop seeing it!

We have all been guilty at times for practicing moral therapeutic deism at one time or another. However, most of us have been completely unaware of this deeply sinful practice due to our western world view. In this episode, we are going to give easy pointers to identify "do more Christianity" and the pervasive moral therapeutic deism. We will also hope to encourage you with practices that can help you identify christ-centered bible reading and preaching.

Freedom from a works-based religion produces rest and assurance in Christ's finished work. I can't wait to talk with you all this Monday at 8:30PM CST.

Moralistic Therapeutic Deism comes from sociologist Christian Smith
It is a combination of beliefs producing a General religious outlook in American teens. Five core beliefs make up what is believed.

____________________________________________________________________________________

Moralistic 
moralistic because it ‚Äúis about inculcating a moralistic approach to life. It teaches that central to living a good and happy life is being a good, moral person.‚Äù

Therapeutic

Therapeutic means it is ‚Äúabout providing therapeutic benefits to its adherent‚Äù Thus it is not about things like ‚Äúrepentance from sin, of keeping the Sabbath, of living as a servant of a sovereign divine, of steadfastly saying one's prayers, of faithfully observing high holy days, of building character through suffering¬†...‚Äù

Deism 
Deism is the "belief in a particular kind of God: one who exists, created the world and defines our general moral order, but not one who is particularly personally involved in one's affairs‚Äîespecially affairs in which one would prefer not to have God involved."

____________________________________________________________________________________

Moral Therapeutic Deism promotes individualism, perpetuates materialism, and tolerates disengaged apathy. As a result of these factors, we are more willing to believe in peace than to live peacefully, to believe inequality more than to treat others equally, to believe in promises of abundance more than to work to create abundance for all, to believe in a friendly divine benefactor interested in our well-being more than to concern ourselves with justice for others.‚Äù 

A church inward focuses and not mission-focused.
Moralistic Therapeutic Deism has little to do with God or a sense of divine mission in the world. It offers comfort, bolsters self-esteem, helps solve problems, and lubricates interpersonal relationships by encouraging people to do good, feel good, and keep God at arm‚Äôs length.

title: Do We Become Gods? A Look at Theosis with Dr. Michael Heiser
description:
Do We Become Gods? | Can We Become Gods? | Theosis Explained | Theosis Debate | Theosis Unpacked | Theosis and Michael Heiser

What does it mean to be partakers of the divine nature, what does it mean to be adopted into the divine family of God, and what is the ontological nature of those who are born again?

Dr. Michael Heiser with Naked Bible Podcast is back tonight to discuss "theosis." It's Doc Heiser, so you should expect that we will discuss Second Temple Judaism, early church fathers, and the Eastern Orthodox church.

It's my hope that we can distinguish the early church fathers' doctrine of theosis from the ever-growing heresies found in Mormon temple and the "Little God Doctrine" sneaking into some 
Word of Faith churches. 

#remnantradio #michaelheiser #theology #theologypodcast #theologydiscussion #theosis 
____________________________________________________________________________________
WHAT IS THEOSIS???

Excerpts from
Princeton Theological Monograph Series
Theosis: Deification in Christian Theology
 The closest English equivalent of theosis is "deification." In Christian theology,
theosis refers to the transformation of believers into the likeness of God. Of course,
Christian monotheism goes against any literal "god making" of believers. Rather, the NT
speaks of a transformation of mind, a metamorphosis of character, a redefinition of
selfhood, and an imitation of God. Most of these passages are tantalizingly brief, and
none spells out the concept in detail.

Deification was an important idea in the early church, though it took a long time for
[theosis] to emerge as the standard label for the process. The term was coined by the
great fourth-century theologian, Gregory of Nazianzus. Theologians now use theosis to
designate all instances where any idea of taking on God's character or being
"divinized" (made divine) occurs, even when the term [theosis] is not used. And of
course, different Christian authors understood deification differently.
 It is difficult to define theosis, but not difficult to cite several biblical passages that
strongly suggest a process of heightened reflection of godly nature, which stimulated
Christian deification discourse. The following grouping of biblical passages is meant to
bring out the logical development of the idea:

title: Why We Practice Spiritual Gifts
description:
Why We Practice The Gifts Of The Spirit

In this video, we discuss the 5 reasons why we practice the gifts of the Spirit. Though this is not to be used as a rock-solid argument against cessationism, we hope this can encourage those who are looking for answers about the gifts of the Spirit. 

First, we discuss how the apostles and the early church used the gifts of the spirit, so we have a president set forth in scripture. Both those in leadership and those in membership have access to the spiritual gifts that God provides.

Next, we discuss how the new testament church is encouraged to use the gifts for the edification of everyone. Paul tells us to earnestly desire spiritual gifts, especially that we would prophesy.

Third, we talked about how Paul commands us not to forbid speaking in tongues, and also tells us not to despise prophecy. How can we follow the commands of scripture to desire spiritual gifts if the gifts have ceased? How are we supposed to obey the command to "not forbid prophecy" or "do not forbid speaking in tongues" if the gifts are not for the church today? 

Forth, the gifts of the spirit are for the edification of the church. They are good for the body, the gifts edify, educate, supply the needs of the church, and build the faith of those who are being ministered to. 

Finally, we discussed how the gifts of the spirit have never ceased from the historical record. The gifts of the spirit have been used throughout history.

title: Brian Head Welch
description:
Guys, Brian Head Welch from the band Korn is coming on the show this week! Can't wait for the show. We will be live this Sunday at 6:45PM

If you do not know Brian. BRIAN ‚ÄúHEAD‚Äù WELCH, was born June 19, 1970, and grew up in Bakersfield, California. He found his calling at age eleven when he picked up his first guitar. Voracious practicing and a steady diet of hard rock classics filled in the ensuing years, and shortly after high school, he co-founded a metal band named Korn. The band soon became a Grammy award-winning, multi-platinum force that shot to the top tier of the rock world and dominated the new metal movement of the late Nineties. Korn‚Äôs 1998 Follow the Leader album cemented the band as rock titans when they debuted at number one on the Billboard charts, fighting off new releases from mainstream heavyweights Dr. Dre and Celine Dion. For his efforts with Korn, Head received six Grammy nominations, winning two, while selling some 40 million records worldwide. 

After becoming a born again Christian, Welch left the band in 2005 to focus on life as a father and to pursue his own solo career. He released his debut Christian album, Save Me from Myself, in 2008. He reunited with Korn on-stage at the Carolina Rebellion on May 5, 2012 for the first time in seven years

title: Women in Ministry: Addressing the complementarian egalitarian debate
description:
Joshua Lewis, Michael Miller, and Guest Jeff Jenkins (https://myanchorchurch.com) will be tackling the complementarian-egalitarian conversation this Monday. We will be answering questions like. Can women be senior pastors? Can Women preach on during the gathering of a churchwide assembly? What should we think about women Pastors? Can women serve in the ministry?

There is a plurality of opinions on this topic, and we hope to do a good job of representing them all. Tune in this Monday at 8:30PM CST to watch the program. If you would like to call in and ask your questions our phone lines will be open to take your calls. In the meantime feel free to ask your questions in the comments.

Complementarian Definition:
Men and women are absolutely equal in essence, dignity, and value and are complementary by divine design. Gender does not merely represent a social construct but, instead, represents a reality present in every human from birth. Men and women are not interchangeable. From the opening pages of Scripture, we find that God, in His wisdom and providence, created two complementary sexes for our good and His glory. In light of His good created order, and the fact that men and women both share in divine image bearing, God intends for men and women to have different yet complementary roles and responsibilities in the church and home.

These role distinctions do not arise from cultural definitions of masculinity and femininity but are an integral part of God‚Äôs plan for humanity, as revealed in Scripture. We should recognize them as God‚Äôs grace to men and women, protecting, preserving and practicing them for His glory, our joy and for the sake of human flourishing. 
https://thevillagechurch.net/Content/ExternalSite/Documents/Beliefs/Institute%20-%202017%20-%20The%20Role%20of%20Women%20at%20The%20Village%20Church%20-%20Full%20Version.pdf

Egalitarianism Definition:
Is the theological view that not only are all people equal before God in their personhood, but there are no gender-based limitations of what functions or roles each can fulfill in the home, the church, and the society. It is sometimes referred to as biblical equality. Egalitarians understand the Bible as teaching the fundamental equality of women and men of all racial and ethnic groups, all economic classes, and all age groups, based on the teachings and example of Jesus Christ. It should not be confused with secular political, economic, social egalitarianism.

title: What are the Tongues of Angels? Talking Tongues with Dr. Sam Storms
description:
In this episode of The Remnant Radio, hosts Joshua Lewis and Michael Miller are joined by Dr. Sam Storms for an in-depth exploration of the gift of tongues, often referred to as heavenly languages. Dr. Storms, an acclaimed theologian and author, brings his scholarly insights and biblical expertise to the discussion, providing clarity on one of the most debated spiritual gifts.

In this episode, we tackle key questions, including:
1) Are heavenly languages always known languages?
2) Is it appropriate to speak in tongues publicly?
3) Did Simon the Sorcerer witness the apostles imparting the gift of tongues to the Samaritans?
4) Are heavenly languages the initial physical evidence of the Spirit's baptism?

Dr. Storms has recently released a book on heavenly languages, which stands out as one of the most thorough and thoughtful works on the subject. His commitment to biblical fidelity and practical guidance offers listeners a balanced perspective on the practice and theology of tongues.

Throughout the conversation, Dr. Storms emphasizes the importance of pursuing a heavenly prayer language while maintaining unity within the body of Christ, avoiding the creation of two classes of Christians: the "haves" and the "have-nots." His approach encourages believers to earnestly seek spiritual gifts while adhering to scriptural parameters.

Join us for an enlightening discussion that challenges misconceptions, deepens understanding, and inspires a renewed pursuit of spiritual gifts within the church. Whether you're a charismatic, a skeptic, or somewhere in between, this episode offers valuable insights that will enrich your faith journey.

Pick up Dr. Storm's Book
https://amzn.to/2Vcnh6h

title: Does the Bible Have a Spiritual Meaning? Understanding the Dangers of Spiritualizing Scripture
description:
We explore the controversial practice of spiritualizing Scripture, where revelatory interpretations, often called "Rhema words" or "fresh bread," are derived from biblical texts. While common in some charismatic circles, this approach can lead to significant theological errors. By grounding their analysis in sound hermeneutics, they emphasize the importance of understanding Scripture within its original context to avoid these pitfalls.

In this episode, Joshua and Michael highlight the dangers of overemphasizing certain texts at the expense of their intended meaning. They illustrate this with examples such as interpreting David‚Äôs five stones as symbolic of the fivefold ministry or viewing Paul‚Äôs encounter with the snake in Acts as a metaphor for revival. While these interpretations can be creative, they often distort the true message of Scripture and mislead believers. Joshua and Michael stress the critical distinction between exegesis, which draws out the text's original meaning, and eisegesis, which imposes external ideas onto the text.

Joshua and Michael also share personal reflections on their experiences with spiritualizing Scripture, explaining how they have come to appreciate the importance of context in biblical interpretation. They emphasize that while Scripture is spiritually discerned, teaching must align with the text's historical and literary context. Misusing Scripture in a revelatory manner can lead to false teachings, harm congregants' faith, and ultimately undermine the authority of God's Word.

Listeners are invited to engage with the content by calling in during the live show to share their own experiences and questions related to spiritualizing Scripture. This interactive segment provides a platform for community learning and support, allowing for a broader discussion on the real-life consequences of misinterpreting biblical texts.

To conclude the episode, Joshua and Michael underscore the need for pastors and teachers to distinguish between personal prophetic insights and authoritative scriptural teaching. They caution against using narrative texts as primary sources for spiritual lessons without acknowledging their historical and literary context. By advocating for sound exegesis, they aim to equip listeners with the tools to discern and apply Scripture correctly in their spiritual lives.

Don't miss this essential episode of Remnant Radio, where deep theological discussions meet practical insights. Subscribe now on YouTube, and join Joshua Lewis and Michael Miller every Monday at 8:30 p.m. CST for more engaging and thought-provoking content. Keywords to look for include spiritualizing Scripture, biblical interpretation, Rhema word, fresh bread theology, exegesis vs eisegesis, continuationism, allegorical interpretation, charismatic theology, misinterpretation of Scripture, and hermeneutics.

title: Filled with the Spirit: Dr. Jack Deere
description:
In this episode of Remnant Radio, Joshua Lewis and Michael Miller engages in a thought-provoking conversation with Dr. Jack Deere about the profound topic of being filled with the Spirit. Contrary to common misconceptions, Dr. Deere offers a nuanced perspective on what it truly means to be filled with the Holy Spirit, drawing from extensive biblical scholarship and personal experience.

Dr. Jack Deere, a seasoned theologian, author, and former seminary professor, joins the discussion by sharing his journey from skepticism to belief in the gifts of the Spirit. He recounts his transformation from a cessationist viewpoint to a vibrant faith in the ongoing work of the Holy Spirit, highlighted by miraculous healings and profound spiritual experiences.

Throughout the episode, Dr. Deere meticulously explores various scriptural references to being "filled with the Spirit", particularly in the writings of Luke and Acts. He clarifies the distinction between different terms such as "filled with the Spirit," "baptized with the Spirit," and "full of the Spirit," and how they relate to empowering believers for evangelistic witness and prophetic testimony.

Dr. Deere also addresses the experiences of John the Baptist, Elizabeth, Zechariah, and the early apostles, emphasizing how their encounters with the Holy Spirit enabled them to boldly proclaim the gospel, often in the face of hostile audiences. He provides a compelling argument that being filled with the Spirit is not about general empowerment for Christian living but a specific, repeatable, temporary empowering for evangelistic testimony.

The conversation is rich with theological insights, practical examples, and personal stories, making it a must-watch for anyone interested in deepening their understanding of the Holy Spirit's work in the life of a believer.

Join us as we delve into this enlightening discussion, challenging traditional views and encouraging a more biblically grounded approach to the work of the Holy Spirit.

title: How To Preach Scripture: Mastering Expository Preaching with Dr. Jim Shaddix
description:
How To Preach Scripture: Mastering Expository Preaching with Dr. Jim Shaddix
In this engaging episode of Remnant Radio, Joshua Lewis and Michael Miller delve into the intricacies of preaching the gospel with Dr. Jim Shaddix from Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary. The conversation spans a range of topics, including the definition of preaching, the importance of expository preaching, and the challenges of topical sermons. Dr. Shaddix shares insights from his extensive experience in pastoral ministry and theological education, emphasizing the necessity of integrity in both the interpretation and application of Scripture.

Dr. Shaddix also discusses the role of the Holy Spirit in the preaching moment, differentiating between being filled with the Spirit and the fullness of the Spirit as character qualities. He explains how the Spirit's work is evident during the proclamation of God's Word and underscores the importance of aligning oneself with the principles of Scripture through prayer and diligent study.

The episode addresses common issues in modern preaching, such as moral therapeutic deism and the misuse of biblical texts to fit contemporary agendas. Dr. Shaddix advocates for a faithful and contextual approach to Scripture, ensuring that the preaching moment is marked by the Spirit's power and presence.

Listeners will find valuable guidance on identifying healthy expositional preaching and understanding the critical role of preaching in the life of the church. Dr. Shaddix concludes with a discussion on his recent book, "Decisional Preaching," which emphasizes the need for preachers to compel their audiences to respond to the truth of God's Word.

title: The Greatest Christian Thinkers In History: Interview with Dr. Ken Samples:
description:
Join Joshua Lewis, Michael Miller, and the Remnant Radio team for an enlightening episode as we dive deep into the lives and contributions of classical Christian thinkers with Dr. Ken Samples from Reasons to Believe. Dr. Samples, an esteemed philosopher and theologian, shares his insights on pivotal figures who have shaped modern Christendom and theological thought.

In this episode, we cover:
Introduction to Classical Christian Thinkers: Dr. Ken Samples introduces us to key theologians and their significant contributions to Christianity. These thinkers include Irenaeus, Athanasius, Augustine, Anselm, Thomas Aquinas, Martin Luther, John Calvin, Blaise Pascal, and C.S. Lewis.

Athanasius and the Arian Controversy: Discover the critical role of Athanasius in defending the doctrine of the Trinity against Arianism. Learn about his famous stance, "Athanasius contra mundum" (Athanasius against the world), and his enduring legacy in Christian orthodoxy.

Thomas Aquinas and Aristotelian Influence: Explore how Thomas Aquinas synthesized Christian theology with Aristotelian philosophy, his monumental works like Summa Theologica, and his profound impact on both Catholic and Protestant thought.

Blaise Pascal's Contributions: Delve into the life and work of Blaise Pascal, his revolutionary ideas in probability theory, and his famous Pascal's Wager. Understand his profound spiritual experience and its influence on his apologetic writings.

C.S. Lewis and Modern Apologetics: Appreciate the depth and breadth of C.S. Lewis's contributions as a lay theologian, apologist, and author of The Chronicles of Narnia and Mere Christianity. Understand his unique approach to Christian apologetics and his lasting influence on contemporary Christian thought.

The Importance of Church History: Dr. Samples emphasizes the need for evangelicals to reconnect with church history, understand the development of key doctrines, and appreciate the intellectual heritage passed down through the centuries.

The Role of Reasons to Believe: Learn about Dr. Samples's ministry with Reasons to Believe, an organization dedicated to integrating science and faith, and providing robust apologetic resources to believers and skeptics alike.

Dr. Samples also shares personal anecdotes, discusses the challenges faced by these historical figures, and provides practical advice for those looking to delve deeper into the study of classical Christian thinkers.

Amazon Link For Dr. Ken Samples Book
https://www.amazon.com/Classic-Christian-Thinkers-Kenneth-Richard/dp/1886653054

title: Molinism explained
description:
In this Christian Theology Podcast Michael Miller Gabe Jones and Joshua Lewis discuss Molinism. Molinism (a theological position named after 16th century Jesuit theologian Luis de Molina), is an increasingly popular model for reconciling God's sovereignty and providence with human freedom and choice. Molinists maintain that God knows what we would do in counterfactual situations (middle knowledge), and that God uses this knowledge to accomplish his goals. In this video, William Lane Craig explains the doctrine.

We hope you enjoyed this Episode of The Remnant Radio, Be blessed.

title: Four Different views of sovereignty

How sovereign is God? Does God predestine good and evil?  Does God sovereignly give us free will?  Does God present us with options while still determining the outcome? Or is the future a mystery to God?  We discuss all this and more on this episode of The Remnant Radio.

title: Classical Apologetics: With Dr. Ken Samples
description:
Classical Apologetics: With Dr. Ken Samples

In this theology podcast Kenneth R. Samples (a scholar from Reasons to Believe) joins Josh Lewis on The Remnant Radio to discuss the classical Apologetic arguments. We discuss the Cosmological Argument, the Teleological argument, the Ontological argument, the Moral Argument, the Transcendental Argument, and Presuppositional Arguments.

Cosmological argument ‚Äì Argues that the existence of the universe demonstrates that God exists. Various primary arguments from cosmology and the nature of causation are often offered to support the cosmological argument.

Teleological argument ‚Äì Argues that there is a purposeful design in the world around us, and a design requires a designer.

Ontological argument ‚Äì Argues that the very concept of God demands that there is an actual existent God.

Moral Argument ‚Äì Argues that there are objectively valid moral values, and therefore, there must be an absolute from which they are derived.

Transcendental Argument ‚Äì Argues that all our abilities to think and reason require the existence of God.

Presuppositional Arguments ‚Äì Argues that the basic beliefs of theists and non-theists require God as a necessary precondition.

As a Reasons to Believe scholar Ken has a great passion to help people understand and see the truth and relevance of Christianity's truth-claims. His writings and lectures at Reasons to Believe focus on showing how the great doctrinal truths of the faith (the Trinity, the Incarnation, the Atonement, creation ex nihilo, salvation by grace, etc.) are uniquely compatible with reason. This approach reflects the historic Christian apologetic statement - "faith seeking understanding." To listen to more from Ken, visit his website at reasons.org

title: Systematic Theology: Christology
description:
Systematic Theology: Christology

Systematic theology is a discipline of Christian theology that formulates an orderly, rational, and coherent account of the doctrines of the Christian faith. Related disciplines are dogmatics, ethics, apologetics, and philosophy of religion.

Christology is the field of study within Christian theology which is primarily concerned with the ontology and person of Jesus as recorded in the canonical Gospels and the epistles of the New Testament.

Who are we talking about today? Well, I'll give you a hint. His last name is "Christ" he has the power of flight, and he can heal leopards.

No, but seriously, in this episode of Lunchtime theologians, Josh Lewis, Jeff Gray, and Michael Mitchell talk about the heretical doctrines that surfaced during the early church, and how the early creeds of the church combated these heresies. We discuss the Hypostatic Union, The Apostles Creed, The Nicene Creed, and proper trinitarian theology.

title: Systematic Theology: Theology Proper (Part 3)
description:
Systematic Theology: Theology Proper (Part 3)

In last weeks Episode of The Remnant Radio, we asked: "If God, then why the Christian God?". This Episode of The Remnant Radio we continue our discussion on Systematic Theology. 

We were cut off last week and were unable to talk about God's imminence and his Transcendence. So we start the show off discussing Gods Trancendence and God's Imminence and we briefly discuss the creation. However, most of this episode is dedicated to the discussion of Trinitarian theology at great lengths.  

What are the dangers of the Arianistic Heresy, Sabelianistic Heresy, and the modalistic heresy? Are the son and the spirit created by the father? Is God simply one being who manifests in three different ways? In this episode, we will discuss the Nicene Creed and the Caledonian creed and how they help us understand the Trinity through a confessional practice. 

We hope you enjoy this Christian Theology Podcast. Be blessed

title: Systematic Theology: Theology Proper Part 1 (Is there a God?)
description:
Systematic Theologians: Theology Proper Part 1 

In this Christian Theology Podcast,  we discuss Systematic theology Part 1. Systematic theology is a discipline of Christian theology that formulates an orderly, rational, and coherent account of the doctrines of the Christian faith. Related disciplines are dogmatics, ethics, apologetics, and philosophy of religion.

Theology proper is the sub-discipline of systematic theology which deals specifically with the being, attributes, and works of God. In a Christian and Trinitarian setting, this study includes pneumatology (the study of the Holy Spirit) and Christology (the study of Jesus Christ).

In our discussion, Michael Mitchel Joshua Lewis and Jeff Gray discuss the 5 classical arguments for theism. The ontological, teleological, cosmological, and moral arguments to answer the question, "is there a God?". This is part one in a systematic theology mini-series called "lunchtime theologians". We hope you enjoy this episode of The Remnant Radio. Be blessed

title: Trinitarian Theology with Dr. Scott Horrell (Part 2)
description:
Part one was so powerful we had to do a part 2. We are so honored to have Dr. Scott Harrell with us to discuss trinitarian theology. Dr. Horrell has been a missionary and theologian in various world cultures, in addition to evangelism and church-planting with World Team, InterVarsity, and Youth with a Mission (YWAM). Along with teaching in several seminaries and cofounding and editing a leading Latin American theological journal, he has written several books in Portuguese and English. He serves as adjunct faculty at SETECA (Guatemala), JETS (Jordan), and CDL (Mozambique). Dr. Horrell is currently A professor of theological studies at Dallas Theological Seminary. He desires to strengthen believers in the doctrinal truths of the Bible, a Trinitarian framework of life, and an understanding of global Christian faith. 

This program is promised to educate, inspire and challenge what you believe and why you believe it.

Josh Lewis' Church Kings Fellowship Church
